Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After completing for you, O Sons, this book which is the last in the science of medicine along with its complement, and having reached the end of it through expositions and declarations thereof, it appeared to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since operation with the hand is laid low in our region and during our time entirely unavailable; until perhaps it has perished altogether along with its knowledge, and the trace of it has vanished; and only small descriptions of it remain in the books of old, which have been changed by hands; and error and hesitation occurred to them, causing their intentions to be enclosed and the force of it to be elongated: It appeared to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise according to the way from expositions, declarations, and abbreviation; and that I should come with forms of iron tools of Cautery and other instruments of work; with a declaration's addition and with proper consideration for what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why a good craftsman of this art is not found with his hand in our time is: because the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained before that in the science of anatomy, as Galen narrated, until he knows the remedies for limbs, their shapes, their connection and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, and their number, their exit points, the pulses of veins and arteries, and their resting places; and the locations where they emerge.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And for this reason, Hippocrates said that name with name is much, and work is little, especially in the art of hands.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already said about it at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 Because whoever is not learned about what we have said concerning anatomy, will not be able to avoid falling into error, in which people are killed: as I have seen many of those who are formed from this science and boast about it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 What is more, I have seen a foolish doctor cut an aposteme from the neck of a woman and he cut some arteries at her neck; therefore, the woman's blood flowed until she fell dead in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 I have also seen another doctor who presumed to extract a stone from an old man, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 Therefore he went to him, and extracted it with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 Thus the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 And indeed I had been called to extract it; and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the man that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 I have also seen another doctor who was receiving a staff at a certain Duke of our land because of medicine; and a black eunuch was with him, who had a fracture near his heel; and the doctor with his ignorance strung the fracture on a wound with pulleys and strong bands, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 Then he closed it according to his own devices.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 Afterwards he let him go for a few days and ordered him not to loosen the band; and he stood like that until an aposteme grew on his leg, and his foot; and he came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 I was then called to him; and I hurried to loosen the band; and calm came over him, and he was released from his pain.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 The corruption had already been confirmed in the member; and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Stop, the corruption has stopped walking around in the member, until it perishes.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 And I saw another physician who pierced a cancerous boil; and it healed after days, until the malignancy of its master was revealed along with him.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 Because when the cancer is pure from black bile, then it is not necessary to reach for it with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can tolerate it, so that the entire thing may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And because of that [saying], O Sons, it is necessary for you to know that the operation is divided into two divisions; namely, an operation associated with health; and an operation with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already aroused myself in every place of this book where the operation comes, in which there is fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore, it is necessary for you to be cautious about it and divide it so that fools do not find a way to speak and disgrace themselves.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Take the measure with care and protection, and treat your weak ones with ease and firmness, and use a better way leading by the grace of God to salvation and praiseworthy success; and dismiss the dreadful illnesses difficult to cure; and free your souls from that which makes you fear, so that hesitation enters upon you in your faith and comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it remains more to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your profit.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 Galenus said it in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat an evil illness, lest you be called an evil physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters. ¶
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On Cautery with fire, and Cautery with sharp medicine, this chapter is dedicated, and it is ordered from head to foot, and the shapes of instruments, and tools for Cautery, and everything necessary for the operation. (¶ denotes a new topic or paragraph)
Capitulum secundum.	 De purgatione venae cum igne calido et medicina acuta
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 On purging a vein with hot fire and sharp medicine, chapter two is dedicated. It covers sectioning, perforation, phlebotomy, and ventosis; wounds; extraction of arrows and similar objects, and everything concerning the shapes of instruments. (¶ denotes a new topic or paragraph)
Capitulum tertium.	 De uulneribus a bestiis feris et hominibus inf
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 On wounds inflicted by wild animals and men, chapter three is dedicated. It covers restoration, dislocation, cure for twisting, and similar issues; from head to foot, and the shapes of instruments. Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be the glory. (This is a common Latin phrase that signifies hum
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 On the benefits and harm of cautery, when it should be used and at what time; and whether with iron or gold. (¶ denotes a new topic or paragraph)
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 But first, before discussing the operations with it, it is necessary to explain the benefits and harm of it, and under what circumstances it should be applied. (This seems to be an incomplete sentence.)
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 I say that the discussion of the quality of the benefit and harm of cautery is a long, subtle, scientific, and hidden discourse. (This seems to be an incomplete sentence.)
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 Moreover, a great number of wise men have spoken about it and have disagreed; and for me, enough is said from their discussions, fearing prolongation. (This seems to be an incomplete sentence.)
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 I say that cautery is suitable for every circumstance, whether with matter or without matter; except for two circumstances, which are a hot dry condition without matter, and a dry cold condition without matter. (This seems to be an incomplete sentence.)
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 In a hot and dry composition, matter has separated.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 Some say that the beneficial cautery is in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others have said the opposite of that, namely that cautery is not suitable in the disease which is due to heat and dryness: because fire is warmth; it is inconvenient to be healed from a hot and dry disease by what is warm and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he who says the opposite of that has said: that by cautery there is benefit in every hot and dry disease which happens in human bodies: because when you compare a man's body and his humors to fire, you find a man's body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I myself say by that speech: because from experience it has often been demonstrated to me.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 Nevertheless, it is not appropriate for that to come about unless he who has been proven and trained in the chapter of cautery's practice at the end, and knows the differences in human compositions, and the dispositions of diseases in themselves, and their causes, and their symptoms, and the time periods of these.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 As for the remaining compositions, there is no fear over you; and especially in cold and moist diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 For now all physicians agree on these: and they have not separated in benefit with cautery in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, sons, that from the secret of healing with cautery with fire, and its goodness over cautery with medicine burning, is that fire is simple, whose action does not extend beyond the member which is cauterized: and it does not harm another joint connected with it, unless minor damage.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of burning medicine extends to what is distant from members: and perhaps it causes difficult healing disease in the member, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 Fire, on account of its subtlety and goodness of substance, does not do that unless it is in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 It has become known to us through experience, on account of the length of servitude and study required with art, and because of its truth-station: and on that account I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not, because it is not permitted to this book of mine, I would reveal to you the secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies by which it expels illnesses, demonstrated by philosophical speech which would be understood by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, sons, that they themselves differ as to the time when a cautery should be made, and they set a better time for truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that a cautery is fitting at any time: therefore because the harm resulting from time is submerged in the help which is attracted by the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if the cautery is for pains resulting from necessary, strong, urgent pains that do not bear delay: therefore because it is feared that from these there may occur a greater evil which would exceed the small harm caused by time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	 And that may not occur to your minds, sons, that it is not thought by anyone except the common people and foolish doctors, namely that there is no return for an illness which is cured by cautery: and they put this consequence, and things are not as they think: therefore because cautery is not, unless in place of medicine, which changes complexion, and expels humidities which are the causes, wherefore pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 However, the cautery is superfluous over medicine on account of the swiftness of its health, and the virtue of its operation, and the violence of its rule: and it is possible that an illness returns at some hour of time according to the complexion of the sick person, and the location of his illness, and the power of its action: and that it prepares in his body from accumulations in it: and that it comes to him from food and similar things from the causes, unless an illness occurs for which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 A subtle ailment in the member of few superfluidities and humidities, like cauterization of a tooth, due to pain, and similar to it, is possible, for it may not return into him that pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 That occurs in a few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 But indeed the common speech, that cautery is the last remedy, is true: not regarding what they intend in it, since they believe that there is no cure given with medicine nor with anything after the fall of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 But the fact is contrary to theirs, and their intent, that cautery is the last remedy, is not, unless when we administer modes of treatment in any ailment, and they do not give such cure with medicine: then we administer cautery at the end, and it cures: thence comes the notion that cautery is the last remedy, not according to their understanding as the common people and most foolish doctors.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron; and they did not say this except for the equality of gold, and the subtlety of its substance; and they said that it does not make a place for cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 But that is not absolutely true; because I have already proven it, and I found that it does not do this in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 And indeed cautery with itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 But indeed when you fire cautery in a fire from gold, it is not manifested to you when heated according to the amount that you wish, due to the redness of gold; and when it approaches the heat, and if you add more heat to it, it liquefies in the fire, and turns into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 Therefore the craftsman falls from that occupation; and for this reason we use cautery with iron among us more quickly and closely to the operation, for rightness in the work.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 I have already arranged this Chapter in Cautery, according to the chapters: and I have arranged it from head to feet: so that it may be relieved for whoever seeks what he wants from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 On the method of cauterizing the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 Here is the cauterization for mastery of humidity and coldness on the brain: these are the two causes of soda (seizures), and the flow of many fluids from the head to the eyes and ears, and the multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain: and universally all illness that happens due to coldness, such as paralysis, and soda (seizures), epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar conditions.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is that you should instruct the sick person: to evacuate first with purifying medicine washing the head for three or four nights, according to the strength of the sick person, and his age, and his custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then instruct him to rub his head with a new linen cloth.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then make him sit between your hands in a square shape, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then place the palm of your hand on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with an unburned (cauterized) mark.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then heat the cautery oil: of which this is the form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then place it (the cautery) on the marked spot without burning, while gradually pressing with your hand, and you turn it around.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Lift your hand quickly, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that a piece of bone or pieces of hair have come out from the skull, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, press your hand with the iron itself or with another if it becomes cold: until the bones that I told you appear.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take something from salt, and dissolve it in water, dip the cloth in it, and place it on the spot: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place on top of it a wet cloth in butter, and let it remain until the burn is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with four-ingredient ointment, until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 It is said that the larger the wound remains open, the more pus it discharges; therefore, it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 Some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone; and the cautery must be held until something of the bone's thickness is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then grind away what has been burnt from the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 Others say that when the cautery reaches the bone, an impression should be made on it for as long as the bone falls off, so that the shape of a corkscrew is formed; or an instrument similar to what women use to insert when they alphabetize letters, and they believe that vapors from the head are released from this place, and the wound should be kept open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then treat it until it solidifies.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 But I do not see these two types of cautery at all, except in certain humans according to the path of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And let it be, it is better for its safety with me.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 The head weakens from the solution of its own continuity; as we have been witnesses in other members; and especially when the head is naturally weak; the first type of cautery is safer and better for me, and I use it; so operate with it for safety.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 Chapter on cauterizing the head when there is pain in the whole head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When a chronic pain occurs throughout the head, and it persists in the weak, and uses warm baths, and leeching, and purges, and oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And especially if it has already been cauterized with one iron as we have said, and it does not help him with any of these, then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 If the head of the weak is strong by nature and not frail, and finds a violent cold, then cauterize it with another iron, but only slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize it over the entire horn of his head with iron, so that the skin is not penetrated and a quantity from the bone, as we have said, is exposed.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 And cauterize it with one iron at the occiput of his head, in a place called vasa: and it is a place where air is placed: pour your oil into this, and do not expose bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 The weak finds it because of that violent pain, and different from the pain of all other cauterizations of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I say that this cautery is in its place, and it should be a cautery for the horns of the head and the occiput more subtle than the cautery used for the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterizing a hemiplegia, both with hot medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When there is pain and swelling in part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and it is cleansed with purifying medicines, and further treatment is given as I said in the divisions of diseases, but it does not help completely, then cauterization is done in two ways: either cauterization with hot medicine burning, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 The cautery with a burning medicine is to take one garlic clove, peel it, and cut off the ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then divide the painful area at the time with a wide lancet until there is a place under the skin where the tooth is captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Insert it into the same place under the skin until it is hidden; then bind over it with a suitable bandage and leave it for fifteen hours; then dissolve it and extract the garlic; leave the wound open for two or three days; afterwards, put a warm poultice soaked in butter on it until a pus forms; then treat it with an ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to do this with certain burning medications as I wrote in the twelfth treatise on poisons.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 The cauterization of this is as follows:
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 Hot Iron Cautery, whose shape is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 Claw-shaped Cautery (also known as Clavilatus): because the head of it is shaped like a nail, having a small notch, and there is a small projection in the middle.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the location and hold your hand; and you pull the iron slowly but quickly; and the quantity that is to be cauterized should be as thick as the skin itself, half of which.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And lift your hand so that an artery, which is below, is not burned and blood flow occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then immerse the wool in water with salt and place it on the location for three days; then immerse the wool with butter, afterwards heal it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this hemiplegia with the tip of a second Cautery (also known as bistoury).
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 Be careful not to cut an artery in this hemiplegia, not an old one specifically.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 § Method of Cauterizing in Old Hemiplegia.
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When you treat hemiplegia, as we said in the previous treatment and what we said in the division of diseases, and healing does not help; and you see from the disease that the first cautery with medicine, or the cautery with fire, did not suffice, then it is necessary to heat a claw-shaped Cautery until it becomes white after marking the location of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or about that; and place your hand once, and press it until you cut the artery, and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 However, it is necessary for you to be careful not to burn the cheek that moves during chewing, so that the side or nerve that moves it does not get burned, thus causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And it should be regarding the care and caution for the flow of blood from an artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 For indeed, in its cutting there is fear, and especially for him who does not know what he is doing, and is not careful, nor experienced. And it dismisses the operation first with such a person.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 And I shall come with the reminder of the management of the flow of blood following the rupture of an artery according to its own method and in its place within this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 If you see from the illness that this cautery does not suffice for him, and you see the body of a weak person tolerating cauterization in the middle of the head as we have said, care for the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you wish, administer the cautery as we have said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 For indeed, cauterization is better and more advantageous in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing pain in the ear.
Caput VI.	 Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When pain occurs in the ear due to cold and is treated with solvents, and other treatment as we have said in division, but the pain does not disappear, then cauterize with fire. And this is what is called Punctum, whose form is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then the punctum is made with it after its ignition all around the ear as it revolves; or around each of them if pain is on both sides.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 And move away from the root of the ear with the cautery a little after marking the places with enkaustricum; and let the quantity of the cautery be ten punctums in every ear, and like that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then care for the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in torture.
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 The torture that is cured with cauterization, is not other than those which occur by phlegm, according to what we said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 Avoid cauterizing species that occur from excision, and also from spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When you treat this species of torture with leeches, purging, and gargles, and your treatment does not bring improvement, then it is necessary that you cauterize the sick person with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and second slightly below its time, and third at the junction of two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 Place your cautery from the weak side of the sick part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Since softening does not occur except in the healthy part.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize yourself with the cautery directly on the upper part of the ear at the very tip below the horn of the head a little: and another in the time, whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 And place your hand with the cautery until the thickness of half the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 And this is the form of the cautery and it is a species from the knife, whose shape has been previously stated: however, it should not be too fine as you can see: and it is necessary that the knife be in it of excessively large thickness a little.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then treat the place with what preceded until healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in old apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 WHEN old apoplexy occurs and your treatment with what we said does not bring improvement, and the sick person does not have a fever, THEN CAUTERIZE HIM WITH FOUR CAUTERIES ON EVERY CORNUS OF HIS OWN HEAD, AND WITH A CAUTERY IN THE MIDDLE OF HIS HEAD, AS WE SAID, AND WITH A CAUTERY AT THE BASE OF HIS HEAD, ACCORDING TO WHAT PRECEDDED: AND THE FORM OF CAUTERIZATION SHOULD BE ACCORDING TO WHAT WAS STATED.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 Also cauterized on the face of the stomach with a Cautery; and it is more extreme.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then it is cured, with what went before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 On the method of cauterizing in Oblivion.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that for the sick there be given first large onions (hyerae), and cleansing pills for the brain (pillulae mundificantes cerebrum).
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then shave the head of the sick person completely, and place on his scalp an ointment made from synapi, as described in the treatise on ointments; and place it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For that is the method of cauterization; and make it according to the same order as I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If therefore he recovers through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not: then make three cauteries on the back of his head, which shall be descending from the top of his head to the lower part of his eye; and place between every cautery a thickness equal to a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then treat the cauteries, with what went before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If you wish an additional treatment, and the sick person is able to bear it; then make a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 If you wish an additional treatment; then cauterize him on both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then treat him until he recovers; and let the cautery be oiled according to the shape that was given before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 On the method of cauterizing in Paralysis, and softening (mollification).
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary to proceed with cleansing the head with onions, and with what was said before.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then shave the head of the sick person; then cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of his head, and on every horn of his head, and on the back of his neck, and three on his spine.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 If however you require the body to be softened in sickness by several of those, and the patient is weak and enduring, and the sickness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries upon the dorsal vertebrae, and the last one with a cautery, until he is burned most from his skin, and you pull your hand away.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then treat him until he is cured: thus cauterize with Olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 An epileptic is not cauterized unless his epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary to clean his brain first with hyssop and the rest of the treatment as we have said in the division; when he is very weak or enduring in taking medications.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 If he is a child who cannot endure medications, then give him gargarism and mouthwashes that clean the brain; beforehand for many days with purifying food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head, afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of the skull, according to what has been said before; and another cautery on the occiput, and over all the horns of the skull with a cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 If he is strong and enduring, then cauterize him with the cauteries as I have said in treating paralysis, and softening of the body upon the vertebrae of the neck and back; and let it be cauterized with olive oil according to the method that has been said before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 If he is weak as a child, then place a subtle cautery in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in melancholy.
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries as I have said in treating paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause is excess of melancholy leading to melancholy, and the body is weakened and damp, then give him a drink that cleanses his brain, as specified in the previous division; then shave the head of the sick person, and make afterwards a well-formed bandage like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it in the middle of the head: and the sick person sitting squarely should be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then apply a liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 It is more suitable from ancient butter from sheep.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat it over a gentle fire, with a measured warmth that the finger can bear when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it on the head of the sick person in a circle and let it remain until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this to the sick person once a week, with the rest of his good regimen, until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small holes in it, but keep your hand with the cautery; let it be fragrant.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cautery dampens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place a warm cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat on it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 [Paragraph break] Method of cauterizing near the eye when descending into water.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When you are informed about the beginning of water in the eye through signs mentioned in the division, then begin and give a drink to the sick person, along with what cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him away from all moisture and make him sit in the bath for a few days while fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then order him to shave his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then cauterize it on two sides with two cauteries, if the descent of water is blocked in both eyes at the same time; or from one side, if the descent of water is blocked in one eye; and cut off with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin; and let the cauterias be long in the width of the temples; and be careful not to cause bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see anything from that, then cut it off immediately with any medicine that is possible; and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their dissection, and precaution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, under two bones, with two lastly produced cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 Chapter on the ancient method of cauterization in the tear-ducts.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are ancient and persistent, being above veins and arteries that are manifest on the outside of the head, it is verified that this is due to an excess of cold phlegmatic humors; then cauterize with the same cautery as I described in the beginning about descending water, with a cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries above the temples, and two cauteries in the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if you need additional treatment, then cauterize it carefully on all sides of the eye, above the eyelid extension with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in nasal foul smell.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you treat it, as we said in the division, and the medicine does not work: then hasten, and give for three nights infirmocochias in drink: then shave his head, and cauterize it with a middle cautery, with the cautery oliuari.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then cauterize it with two cauteries and a clavius cautery, on top of the eyebrows under the hair slightly.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And beware of the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the form of the clavius cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 § On the method of cauterizing in softening the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Head XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of the eye is softened by sickness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this cautery lunare.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it above the eyebrows slightly with two cauteries in all places; and they should extend from both temples; and let the length of the entire cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow; and do not place your hand with the cautery at the very end, rather according to the amount that is burned by the third eyelash.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of the lunare cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 § On the method of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs are turned upwards and prick the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Head XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 The cautery is in this two ways: either a cautery with fire; or a cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 In the cautery with fire, instruct the sick one beforehand to release his hairs, if he is among those who wash them, until they are extended and aligned.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 If however they prick him at the root: then constrain his eyes with a bandage so that they do not move, until new ones grow.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 When they are born and become equal (in size), then place the head of the weak one in your lap; afterwards mark a sign on the eyelids of his eyes with hot wax, a sign which is in the shape of a myrtle leaf; let the beginning of the sign be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then place a wet cloth on the egg white or on the eye, or apply slippery elm poultice to the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then heat an instrument with fire, which has this shape (a trephine or surgical drill).
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize gradually, in several places where you have marked, until the surface of the skin burns, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, completely appearing.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And the mark of the success of your work is that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting and hairs rising up at the corner of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then lift your hand (away), and release him for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then place a warm cloth with butter over it until the scab falls off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If a hair grows back after an hour and the eyelid becomes soft again, then repeat the cautery on that spot, as you did initially.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 If however hairs are below (in the lower lid), then cauterize it until they rise up to their natural position and do not irritate the eye by growing into it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 [Section heading: The manner of cauterizing when using a burning medicine in the same case.]
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 It is necessary to instruct the weak one to pluck out his hairs until they grow longer and become equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make a parchment in the shape of a myrtle leaf from linen cloth.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take some soap that is known and plaster that has not been soaked from one source or the other (equal weights of both), then grind them together with good pressure, but quickly, so it does not get cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then take that (object) and place it on the cloth you have made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and put it upon one or both eyelids.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 Then place under the eye a swab soaked in egg white: and let the head of the sick be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 Place your index finger upon the medicine and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 You move (the swab) whenever the sick person feels a bite from the medicine, because its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While this persists and it continues to feel a bite from the medicine, then release the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When the bite ceases, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 Then consider whether the eyelid rises as it does when heated by fire or cut: if so, it is good; and if not, then repeat the application of medicine over the place where the medicine does not press and does not discolor, until your operation is complete and the eyelid contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place (the swab) over it with butter until the charred skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with diaphine ointment or another ointment until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 It is necessary for you during the operation that you keep the last guard, lest anything fall from the medicine into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If the eyelid becomes softened after days and something comes out of the hair into the eye from that place, then repeat the medicine over that place which has become softened from the eyelid, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that human eyes differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore, according to that, let your consideration be: and the path of righteousness shall not be concealed to him who is devoted to this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 On the method of cauterizing in the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you treat the fistula, if, as we said in our discussion of diseases, your treatment does not help: then it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Command the sick man to place his head on your lap, and let one of his attendants hold his head between his own hands in such a way that it does not move or shake with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then put cotton soaked in olive oil or psyllium mucilage on his eye: then place the cautery iron over it, which has this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 It should be concave, like the form of a bird's feather quill from one end, with which the cautery iron is made: and if you wish it to penetrate to the other end, and if you wish it to extend upward in this manner.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, a concave one is better for your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then, if the fistula is open, unblock it and drain the pus from it, and then excise it: and if it is not open, then open it and drain its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place the hot cautery iron on it.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand near the cautery iron for a little while by the eye, at the side of the nose, so that your hand does not stray or shake the sick man: and you will place the cautery iron on the fat of the eye and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If you reach to the beginning of your cautery as far as the bone, that is good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery once or twice, as needed; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then place the wound with butter, and care for it with an antiseptic ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 If it goes beyond forty days and does not heal, then place a sharp corrosive medicine on top of it until the bone appears: and shave it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some of the first ones said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Approach the place of the fistula and find it: then put a fine cannula into the opening, that is, a thin cannula whose shape is as follows.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 Pour in it a quantity of drachmas of liquid lead, and hold your hand with the cannula's retention good, and do not let it move at all, so that the liquid lead does not run or reach its eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 It is necessary that you place a warm poultice on the eye of the sick person in egg white or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it by a wonderful healing process.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula heals with what we said about cauterizing, and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 If not, then it is necessary to open the nose hole and redirect the fistula towards the nostril, according to its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in facial clefts.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Many times fissures occur in the lip, which are called "Pili", and especially in children's lips.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 When you care for these fissures, as we said in the division of diseases, and the treatment does not help, then use a small cautery iron shaped like this.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 The depression of it (the instrument) should be according to the subtlety of a knife's edge.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then place it (the hot cautery) hastily into the splits (wounds), until the cautery reaches the depth of the splits (wounds).
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it (the wound) with ointment, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 On the method of cauterizing a mouth ulcer.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of the gingiva (gums), or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts: afterwards it becomes old, and the pus runs and becomes a fistula: then take care of it and do not apply treatment to it, then if it does not heal, as required, it is necessary that you heat cauterization according to its quantity, which can be absorbed in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then insert the heated metal (cauterization) into the hole of the fistula and hold your hand until the hot iron reaches its depth and its end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then take care of it afterwards, with what I said about treatment, until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If therefore the pus separates and heals, it will be good (favorable).
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the rotten bone according to its size.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 Chapter on Cauterization in softened gums and teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gums become soft due to moisture and the teeth move, and treatment with medicine does not help; then put the head of a sick person on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then heat the cauterization whose form will come later; so that you place a cannula over a tooth and insert the heated cauterization quickly into it: and hold your hand for a while until the sick person feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And lift your hand: then apply the cauterization several times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then let the sick person fill his own wound with salt water and hold it for an hour: and rinse it.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 Teeth that move are made firm, and softened gums are tightened and dried out the rotten moisture.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 On the method of cauterizing tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	 In capite dentium exterius demodis et interd
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 Chapter XXIII (Head of teeth) on external and internal diseases of the teeth, and their cure. When toothache is due to cold or there is coldness in it, or worms, and no medicine brings relief: then Cautery is used on it according to two methods: either Cautery with butter; or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 The cauterization with butter is as follows: Take lard (butter) and boil it in a cast-iron or copper pot.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then receive the cup and turn it over on the end of the incision.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then immerse it in melted butter and place it on the painful tooth quickly and hold it until it cools; then repeat it several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 And if you want, immerse wool or a cup in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth; then place hot iron on top of it until the heat reaches the depth of the hollow part of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 The cauterization of this, with fire, is to aim at the brass tube or iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 And let there be something bulky in his body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the weak bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then apply the cauterizer (Cautery) with fire and shape it; place it on the tooth and hold your hand until it cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Do this several times as the pain will subside either on the same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 And when applying the impression of the cautery, the weakened bone must be filled with good butter and held for an hour; then it should be spat out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 And this is the shape of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Cauterize with whichever end you wish, depending on what is possible; and this is the shape of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 Section on the method of cauterizing abscesses.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When Warts are from phlegm and from cold moistness, and they do not obey digestion through medicines, and they desire rapid digestion: then to the Curved Cautery, whose shape is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 Having two open ends so that the smoke may exit at the Cautery from one end: and place it heated upon the ulcer once, and again, if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the ulcer.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the ulcer is small: then place the Cautery according to the size of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then let it rest for three days, and place upon it a dish of warm butter soaked until what the fire has burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then care for it with tooth ointment until the form of the pipe (cannula) heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 On the method of cauterizing in a hoarse voice and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When moisture accumulates on the windpipe (trachea), especially when it is accompanied by coldness of complexion, then it is necessary to first remove the weakened one with dissolving medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then cauterize it (the windpipe) in the neck at the root of the throat in a hollow place depressed: and be careful not to reach with the Cautery at the throat or skin unless something of that area is present.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize it (the windpipe) with another cautery at the juncture of the neck in the last rib of that place: and let the Cautery be square-shaped according to the method previously described.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what was previously mentioned until it heals.
