¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 On the method of cauterizing in diseases of the lungs and cough.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	 When cough and sickness of the lungs are from cold moistures, and the person is not feverish, nor consumption, and the sickness is old: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the collarbone in depressed, gentle, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	 With another caution on the middle of the chest between two breasts: and let the caution be of the tube shape, as was before.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	 And if your caution is to be by pricking with the caution called "Punctum", whose shape was before in the pricking of ear pain: and let the pricks be from thirty up to as many more.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with what was before until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	 And now let the caution have three branches: according to this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	 Therefore let the caution be applied when you are using it instead of three cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	 § On the method of cauterizing in the Tilt (Titillico), in the dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	 When the head is dislocated due to assistance and it does not heal within an hour of its return from the dislocation, until such a habit of returning has been established for it, then it should be dislocated slightly as a result of a small movement that occurs just as we have already testified about this. Then you must reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	 Then the sick person lies down on his back or on the healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	 Then peel off the skin that is on the inner side of the Tilt (Titillico) towards the top with your left hand fingers: and if there is a fusion in the internal parts.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	 Then heat the cautery with two openings.
Cuius forma est haec.	 Its shape is as follows: (Drawing not included, but it is described as a "T
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	 Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates through to the other side and forms the shape of the cauterization with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	 And sometimes there is cauterization with a cautery having three prongs, for which the figure of cauterization becomes that of six cauteries: and the prongs are according to the subtlety sought.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	 Here is the form of the cautery having three prongs.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	 And sometimes an additional one is added to it, for which there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	 Then place upon the cautery bent rods with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	 Then make the patient to adhere to calmness, so that a limb is not moved during any time, until it recovers.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	 And if there is a dislocation toward the upper part, which rarely occurs, then cauterize it on the shoulder with an angled cautery or with many pointed cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	 For union strengthens, and moisture is removed: and the sick person recovers.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	 When coldness and many moistures occur in the stomach until it is separated from its composition, and catarrhs multiply on it, and continuous methods of treatment do not help: then the patient should lie down on his back, spread out his legs, and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	 Then cauterize with three cauteries: one angled cautery of the size of a finger under the navel of the chest, and two cauteries below on each side of the one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	 And extend them apart so that they do not join together, when pus will form.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	 And the depth of the cautery should be the size of two thirds of a finger thickness of skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	 And the figure of the cauteries should be according to this shape without addition: and if you wish, cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this shape: and let the cautery used for this cauterization be one according to the shape of a circle according to this shape.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	 The stomach is to be cauterized by piercing it with a probe for those who fear the cautery; and this should be done by making marks on the stomach in proportion to the size desired with an encaustic iron, then cauterize that spot with the point of the cautery; then care for it with the preceding cure until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	 The method for cauterizing a hernia (epar) coldly.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	 When pain occurs in the hernia (epar) due to coldness and moistness, or from a large wind that cannot be expelled naturally through its own expulsion and the patient is ill and not cured by what has been said; then the patient should lie down on his neck, and make three marks with an encaustic iron on the hernia in this manner and this size, below the hypogastrium, where the human arm reaches; and let the space between each cauterization be according to the thickness of a finger; and let the cauterization be according to the length of the body straightly; and do not press your hand with the cautery too tightly.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	 And let the size of what is being cauterized be according to the thickness of the skin, without adding its half; and let the patient stand on his own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	 But if he is not standing, then let him lie down, who has already extended his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	 This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	 It is possible for you to cauterize these cauteries with a knife-shaped cautery when you have subtlety and wisdom in your art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	 And take care not to proceed too deeply in the cauterization, and when the thickness of the skin is being cauterized, the whole body is being cauterized; therefore it reaches the intestines, because the skin there is subtle; therefore know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	 Method for cauterizing abscesses of the Liver.
Caput XXX.	 Surgicis adhibetur in casu qu
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	 When it is required to know if an abscess is in the liver flesh or its covering, and if it is in the liver flesh, there is a dull pain and heaviness without sharpness; but if it is in the liver covering, there is intense pain with sharpness. And now you see that the treatment of this abscess has exhausted the physicians.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	 The sick person should therefore lie down with his head on his chest.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 Then, make the position of the lancet and apply encaustum (hot wax). Then, heat the cautery resembling a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	 And cauterize it with one cautery until the entire skin is burnt and reaches the flesh, so that all pus comes out; then care for it with healing until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	 And one should not use this cauterization method, unless his interest in the art of medicine is prolonged; and for whose hands these diseases are often associated with experience: then he dares to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	 But rather, I prefer to release it myself.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	 Head, Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	 Ancients said that cautery with the roots of arnica to the lungs in this way: cold method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	 And it is to receive from the dry roots of arnica, one longer root which can be found thereof, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	 Then immerse it in oil, and ignite it.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	 Then cauterize with one hot iron in that which is between the continuation of the clavicle with the neck, and with two small irons below at the place that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	 And with two irons also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs slightly downward towards the back, and with another iron in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	 And with three irons from behind: one in that which is between the two scapulas; and with two irons on the sides of the chest, below an iron which is between the two scapulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	 And it is not necessary to press your hand with the iron, on the contrary, let it be in open air smelling of skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	 And some ancients said that there are men who use an iron similar to a probe and heat it up, and they put it inside where the ribs are until they reach the abscess with it, and the pus exits; as we said in the case of the liver abscess.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	 But in this puncturing with the iron there is fear, because either the weak person immediately dies, or a fistula occurs at the place from which there is no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the spleen: XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	 When you treat the sickness of the spleen, as we said in the treatment of diseases and your treatment does not help, then there is cauterization of it according to three methods, which are all correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	 One of them is to make three or four cauteries in the shape of the cauterizations of the liver, where the figure of the liver's cauterization precedes, along its length.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	 And let every cautery have a thickness equal to that of a finger, or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	 The mode of the cautery we mentioned in the liver cautery should be the same.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	 And do not press your hand with the cautery; let him who is being cauterized lie weakened on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	 Another method for cauterization is to have the cautery with two holes and apply it as we said in the chapter on dislocation of the humerus: and lift up the skin that is directly on the spleen, where the elbow of the weakened left arm reaches: and your lifting should be such that you lift the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	 Then insert two holes with very hot fire until they penetrate the skin on the other side; then withdraw the cautery; thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	 And if you wish to cauterize using a cautery with three holes.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	 Then take care of the cautery after releasing it, let it expel pus for many days; for this is more beneficial than the rest that preceded in treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterization in dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	 Cautery does not fall into Hydropisis, unless properly ascliti.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	 When you treat a Hydropic (patient), with the methods of treatment as we have mentioned in the division, and the treatment does not bring improvement, then it is necessary that you cauterize him with four cauteries around the umbilicus, and with one caution on the stomach, and another on the epar, and another on the spleen, and two cauteries behind (him), between the vertebrae, and one in front of the chest, and another in front of the stomach: and let the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	 Then let the open cautery (be left) so that it may discharge pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	 And do not evacuate the sick person after cautery along with him, for it is necessary that two intentions are applied to him: and healing will hasten towards him with God's help.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	 The form of the cautery with which the abdomen is cauterized should be in the shape of a nail: according to its previous form: and that with which the back is cauterized, should be in the shape of an oil flask according to its previous form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing Feet and Legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XLII.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	 When they are amputated in a Hydropic (patient), and filled with citron water: it is necessary that you cauterize on the back of the foot in the navicular bone, which is between the auricular and annular bones: and lift your hand with the cautioner, but do not twist it: then lift your hand again: and do not return to him at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	 For citron water will flow out, and let the cautery be in this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	 Then make two cauteries on each leg, and let the cautery be with the tip of a lancet-shaped cautioner: and let the cautery be along the length of the leg, one below the knee, and another further down, about halfway along the leg: and over the whole hip make two cauteries: and leave the open cautery for a long time without treatment so that some water flows out from it: then treat him as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	 Method of cauterizing in the solution of the abdomen.
Caput XXXV.	 Head XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	 If the solution of the abdomen is caused by cold and humidity, until it weakens the powers retained and digestive, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with methods of treatment, but not healed: and you see a patient tolerating an excessive amount of cauterization due to strong powers, then cauterize it with a large cautery over the stomach, as was done in the cauterization of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four subtle cauteries around the umbilicus, with a subtle cautery on the clavicle, and a large cautery or two cauteries over the alcatin upon the flanks, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	 And if you see excessive humidity and a patient tolerating it, then cauterize it with a large cautery over the breastbone, and a large cautery over the entire ilium: perhaps you will add two small cauteries near the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	 For indeed the treatment is progressing, whose help is not in vain.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	 Method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	 Head XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	 When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are of thick, cold, or corrupted fluids, and are treated as we said in the division, and the treatment does not help: then cauterize three times on the lower part of the backbone slightly triangularly below the almeidati, and cauterize under the navel about two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If you think that his stomach is chilled and food does not digest properly, and you see his face turning pale, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cautery, as was mentioned earlier: and cauterize over the Epar (liver) of his and another one over his Spleen, and also over his clavicle: and leave the open cautery for some time: then take care of him until he is well.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing althelul after excision.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 When you excise althelul, then heat the cautery that resembles a rod.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	 Then introduce the heated cautery into the excised althelul: and your last hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	 If there are many althelul, then cauterize each one with the cautery as we have said.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	 Then take care of them with that which benefits them from ointments until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	 And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on the bladder, it is more effective for healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing anus fistula.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	 If the patient does not obey the incision and operation as we have described at its place, and is afraid of it, he may be cured with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	 When an abscess occurs and breaks, pus flows out from it, and the moisture is corrupted.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	 Therefore, it is necessary to test (it) with a thin probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	 Then, recognize the depth of it by using a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	 Then, prepare a hot cautery that resembles a rod.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	 Then insert yourself into the fistula while burning (and note) the depth at which the nail is inserted.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And repeat the cautery on (it) until all corrupted bodies are burned away, either once, twice or three times, according to your need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	 And take care not to burn a nerve or a large vein if the fistula is there; or if the fistula passes to the body of the bladder or the body of the intestine, then take care away from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	 Do not do this unless the fistula is in a fleshy place; and remember, it does not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	 Then, take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	 If, however, the location is sealed off and the material is removed from it, and it remains for a long time; then you will know that it has healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 If the material is not removed from it, then you will know that it penetrates or there is a rotten bone deep within it; or it is one of these things which we shall remember later in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	 Chapter on cauterizing the Kidney.
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold or large wind, and it weakens the body because of that, then it is necessary to cauterize it on the flank over both kidneys with a cautery throughout the entire kidney with a cautery claw, whose precedent is remembered.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	 And perhaps we cauterize it again in the same flank.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	 Why three lines will come.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	 Therefore they will be more effective in the relief.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	 Section on the method of cauterizing the Bladder.
Caput XL.	 Chapter XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	 When weakness or softening occurs in the Bladder due to cold and moisture, until it is unable to retain urine, then it should be cauterized on the lower part of the back over the Bladder where the hair of the comb begins, and with a cautery from the right side of the back, and another from the left: and let the length of this cauterization on the side be according to the size of the knuckle of the thumb: and it should be cauterized with a lower-back cautery or with two cauteries, if necessary: and it should be done as the preceding cauterium claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	 Section on the method of cauterizing the Womb.
Caput XLI.	 Chapter XLI.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When coldness and moistness occur in the womb, preventing conception, and the menstrua are spoiled, and their calling forth is delayed, and pain occurs at their arrival, then it is necessary that three cauteries be applied around the umbilicus, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and a cautery below on the back, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery be a claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	 On the method of cauterizing the anus in its dislocation.
Caput XLII.	 Chapter XLI (42).
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	 When the moistness of the mucosa flows out to the anus, and it becomes the cause of its exit from its place; and the sign of this is that one leg is extended over another when they are brought together; and a hollow place is found in it (the anus) due to dislocation.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	 Therefore, it is necessary to apply a weak cautery on the anus itself with a similar circular cautery; after you have marked the anus with encaustum (hot wax) in a circle, as they are rolled (the anus); and that the anus falls into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	 And let the cautery be of such a shape as was described in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	 If this cautery is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large oil-burning cautery; and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter XLIII (43).\] Quando accidit Sciat
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	 When pain occurs in the anus and the cause of this is coldness and moistness; and it is treated with what was said above (for other conditions); but the treatment does not help, and it worsens; then it is necessary to dissolve the weakened one with fetid pills or with artificial pills, or similar.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	 Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	 And the method of cauterization is done in two ways: either with a cautery containing medicinal substances or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	 Cauterium with fire, is in many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	 One of these (ways) is to cauterize on top of the ankle pit with three triangular cauteries in this manner.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	 And make it a good or bad depth (for them).
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	 And let the space between every cautery be of the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be greased (with oil).
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	 Sometimes, however, the cautery is made in the middle on top of the ankle pit itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	 Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	 If you want to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded the cautery in the ankle dislocation, one should be: so that the circle contains the entire ankle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	 And burn (or char) the thickness of the skin all over.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	 This is the method of cauterization for sciatica when the pain is attached to the ankle itself and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	 If it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the hip, at the place where the patient indicates that there is pain, and with your own cautery four fingers deep into the woody part (of the affected area); and let the cautery be a knife-like cautery.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery correspond to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	 If the patient indicates that the pain extends towards the toes, then cauterize it there where he points with a needle-like cautery, three, four or more, as needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	 If he indicates that the pain is turned towards the calf of the leg (thigh), then cauterize it there with a knife-like cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	 In every cauterization of yours, be careful not to burn the nerve or a major artery with the cautery, and avoid causing harm or contracture through it.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	 I myself have seen one and another among those who cauterized over the heel, and burned in cauterization, and the leg swelled until the tumor reached the foot, and it was perforated completely, and the whole foot was rotten: then there occurred rupture of the belly, and death followed after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	 If pain is in two parts at once, cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	 And certain wise men have said about the cauterization of the anus, whose cautery this method is.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	 Make a similar instrument of iron, whose diameter is half the width of the palm: and it should be at its opening according to the size of the tip of the thumb or less: and within this instrument there should be a third instrument.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	 And the distance that is between each instrument should be according to the size of the knuckle on the index finger: and the instruments should be open on both sides: and their height should be like a knuckle or two knuckles: and make handles for them of iron properly fitted in the instruments.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	 Then it is heated in the fire until it glows and casts sparks: then place it on a bowl of the weakened anus lying on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	 Therefore, cauterize it with three rounded cauteries at once.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then let it rest for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	 Then apply poultices with butter: and leave the open wound for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then heal it with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	 Says Albucasis, we have not used this type of cautery enough, because of the fear of its appearance: and therefore, few are found who dare to endure it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	 Verumtamen is good for the one who endures [the operation], and it finds its place with him.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	 Cauterium however, with stimulating medicines, is to be made so that you make two knots having a perforated armillary, from which descends the cord of its gate from brass or iron, long as the thickness of the wall: whose height in their nodes should be two, or themselves like.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	 And let there be space between the two which is the thickness of a finger, and it should be open below and above: and let it be able to contain each other according to this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	 Then place it on a box of ankles, with the weak one lying on the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	 And press your hand much upon the box of ankles.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	 Then pour water between the two circles which is heated slightly with fire and hold it for an hour's time: and let the weak one endure its bite and his burn, for he himself finds a bite like fire until the bite ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 Then wipe your hand with the tool and remove warm water from the whole ankle with sweet water: then let it go for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	 And place butter on it until the blackness of the burn is removed: and let it go for some days, and pus will flow out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	 Indeed, it is the last remedy.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	 If the pain extends to the hip or leg: make a splint for him in what contains water, according to what you did in the ankle equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	 This is the method of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	 Take alkali and half a part of unslaked lime from both of them: grind each of them, and put them in a new pot, the lower part of which is perforated with a small hole, according to the quantity that enters it itself radius: and put another earthenware pot below the bottom of the pot: and pour alkali and lime from sweet water on both of them, so that each is submerged by a finger: after this you press them with your good compression: and let go the pot until the acid water comes out from the bottom of the earthenware pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	 Then collect all that water and pour it over another pot, and let it boil until it returns.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	 For indeed, it will then be very strong for sharpness, which is given in many medical operations, and in the cauterization of other members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	 Because it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	 And among the medications are those with which they are cauterized, such as tesisie, and honey of cardamom, and chalk with soap, so that both are mixed together. (Here starts a new paragraph)
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	 And Galen himself, in telling, reported a cure for a man of old, who was cured from pain in the anus and the sciatic vein: and he praised it very much.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	 And he said that it does not need other cure, and because it was cured by one application, until it returned to tell that perhaps he himself had entered the bath, and left already healthy from it.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	 And it is to be taken from the wild green sedge: and if not found, dry one should be taken, fresh: and it should be crushed a lot with some fat, and placed on the anus where there is pain, or leg, or hip: and tied, and left for three hours, or until it feels weakened by the sensation of burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	 Then insert it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	 When his body becomes warm, insert it into the bed.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	 For pain retreats and heals.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	 And know that someone should not use a cautery with these medications unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	 And Dioscorides, who said that the feces of goats, when it is used for cauterizing the sciatic vein, gives it: and it becomes a cautery according to this method.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	 Take wool, and soak it in old oil, and place it on a deep place that is between the toe of the foot and the heel, and near the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	 Then take dry feces of goats and burn it until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	 Place it on wool and let it extinguish.
Deinde itera illud.	 Then repeat this process.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	 Do not stop doing that until the sensation reaches the bone and the pain ceases.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	 And this method of cauterization is called a "Vaccine Cautery".
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	 [Title] On the cauterization of back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	 Occasionally there is pain in the back due to various causes, either from falling, striking, excessive evacuation, and similar things, or from the infusion of cold and moist matter: and cauterization does not occur except in this sole case, which is made by the infusion of cold and moist matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	 Therefore, after evacuation of the sick person with fetid pills and similar things on the back where there is pain, three lines should be drawn according to the width of the almeida itself, after marking with encaustic in each line five cauteries or more according to the amount that comes from the strength of the sick person: and the cauterization should be made with a cautery point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	 And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries, along with the medial claw cautery, according to this shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in the development of humpback.
Caput XLV.	 Chapter XLV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	 This disease often occurs in small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	 The sign of the onset of this condition in children is that it happens above them when they are constricted during a sigh and motion: and you find at the end of the vertebrae of the back and its knots, which have already begun to emerge above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	 When you see this and wish to do it, then cauterize it with a circular cautery of the following shape.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	 And the cautery should cover all parts of the vertebrae equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the vertebrae with a pointed cautery, make two lines or three; and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	 Then take care of the place until it heals as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	 And be careful not to administer the cautery in the humpback that occurs in a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	 On the method of cauterizing in gout, and pains in joints.
Caput XLVI.	 De modis cauteriandi in morbis podagricis, et
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	 When pains in joints are caused by cold humors that flow into any part of the body, and when they occur in the feet, it is the custom among physicians to call it gout properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	 Since gout caused by cold humors does not respond to the usual treatments and the pains persist, then use cautery to remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	 And it is done by cauterizing it after evacuation around the joint of the foot, with many firebrands, and let the cautery be Oliuare.
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	 And if it is necessary to prick the sole of the foot, then do so with a hot iron (cautery).
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	 If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints and this often happens, then cauterize it over all the knee three or four times with a single firebrand, called Clavili.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 If more than one cautery is required, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	 Do not immerse your hand in the cautery, but rather let it be about the thickness of the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	 If the pains ascend to the knees and the back (of the leg), then administer what has been said in the appropriate chapter regarding cautery.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	 If the pains are only in the hands, then prick around the knuckles, as two lines are rolled (or twisted).
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	 If the pains remain in the fingers, then prick them all over, on every knuckle and on the back of the hand (palm).
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	 If the pains ascend after days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	 And do not evacuate a weak person from good diet and medicine reception.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	 If good care is taken and phlegm is drained, it will be healed with God's help by this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	 On the method of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter LIV.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	 When there is a rupture in the groin and the intestine or spermatic cord descends to the testicle, which is just beginning: then it is necessary that you order the patient to abstain from food on their own day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	 And they should use laxatives, so that the feces leave their bowels.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	 Then he should sit on your hands over his back; and order him to hold his breath until the spermatic cord appears or the intestine emerges.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	 Then you should reduce him with your fingers and mark the place of the rupture with hot iron, with a sign whose end is similar to half a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	 Then apply the heated iron cautery, in this shape: until white matter appears and it discharges pus.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	 Then reduce the intestine or spermatic cord to its hollow.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	 Then place an assistant's hand on the location so that the intestine does not escape; and you have already opened between the legs of the patient, placed a pulley under him, and another servant on his thighs and another on his chest holding his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	 Then place the cautery over the mark, with your hand holding the cautery straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	 And hold him until you follow the bone with it; or hold it again in turn if you have not followed it to the bone in the first instance.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	 And be careful to observe the exit of the intestine during your cauterization hour, lest you burn it and it passes over the patient causing death or great harm.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	 And know that when you do not follow the bone with the cautery, your operation is of no use.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	 And it is necessary that the cautery for infants be fine, according to their measurement.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then, care with the remaining ointments, until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	 And let the sick one lie on his back for forty days, until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	 And it is necessary that you place his sustenance in length of the time of treatment for him, so that it will calm his stomach; lest the intestines come out during an attempt at healing and evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	 Then, when he wants to get up after forty days, then administer a well-made bandage and let him hold it for forty more days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	 And let him be less in labor, in filling of food and drink, and violent voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	 For when this regimen is used, thus it heals with a complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	 And I will say the cure for ruptures with an incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	 When ruptures happen in the rest of the belly, and they are beginning, and there is a wish not to add them, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its size: and let it be what is heated from then on as one-third of its size.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	 Then care for him as I have said; do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	 And some of the first ones have said: that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery according to this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	 After it is signed with pitch and a line is placed that is across its width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	 And put your hand in the middle with the curved cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	 But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for pains due to loss or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter LIV.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	 When pain occurs in some members due to accident or blow, and the pain persists for a long time without healing with medications, then it is necessary to cauterize it with the cautery of Point.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	 And let the cautery be for all members according to its size and smallness, weakness and strength, and its location and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	 If it is cured by the first cauterization, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	 If not: then repeat the cauterization on it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	 Because it is a custom of these pains that they are transferred from one member to the neighboring one.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Therefore, follow them with the cautery until the sick part is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	 Chapter on the way of cauterization for Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	 Lepers are sometimes helped by a great benefit from cautery.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	 And especially the kind of leprosy that occurs due to corruption of phlegm and black bile; when you intend to cauterize it, consider this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	 If leprosy is beginning and you have treated it as we said in the division, but it does not decrease or stop; and if you fear that corruption will spread over its entire complexion, then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head at a known spot, and the second lower facing the forehead towards the end of the hair, and two above the horns, and one behind the occiput on the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	 And place your hand with the cautery a little bit more until it makes an impression smaller than the mouth cavity and the scalp separates from it; so that expiration of thick vapors from it is relieved, and cauterize also over the spleen as it preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	 If the leprosy has already spread over the sick person and it is manifestly apparent, then it is necessary to cauterize with these cauteries which we have mentioned earlier, and a cautery upon the extremity of the nose, and two cauteries upon the cheeks, and two cauteries upon the spine of the neck, and six upon the spines of the back, and one large one over the alhahosos near the base of the tail and one upon it, in the almeidati: and two over the ankles: namely, one over the entire anklebone, and two over the knees: one over every knee, and two over the shoulders, and two over the elbows, and two over the tendons of the chest, and cauterize it upon all the joints, from the joints of his fingers on his hands to those of his feet: and cauterize upon all the heels of his feet, and upon the soles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	 Cauterize the nerves which are above the heel bone (calcaneus), so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	 And sometimes a cautery is applied to the back of the head, another to the stomach, and another to the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	 And know that the more cauteries you apply, the more helpful and beneficial it is.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	 And know that the sick person does not feel pain from the cautery, as healthy people do; therefore, because his body has already become numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	 And it is necessary that the cauteries be of various sizes and shapes according to the limbs and joints; this will depend on the type of instrument used.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for the cautery with flour made from herbs mixed with honey, and the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Stupor (numbness).
Caput L.	 Book L:
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	 When a limb becomes numb and is treated with medicines, oils, plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize the numb limb with cauteries, according to the size or shape of the member.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	 Your cautery should go slightly into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	 Sometimes, when cauterizing in the region of the hand and foot, especially in the spine at the nerve exit points that move that limb; remove the stupor (numbness).
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	 But do not presume to act on it unless one is wise in the study of body parts and nerve exits.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Albaraz.
Caput LI.	 Chapter L (Roman numerals for 50).
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	 When Albaraz is ancient and does not receive anything from the skills of medicine; then cauterize on top of it, slightly deepening with a cautery according to the thickness of the skin, until the white disappears and the color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with barley flour and lentils mixed with rose oil, arnoglossus leaves, and the blood of a dove and a frog; each equal part; mix all these together, soak them on a cloth, and apply them to the location until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Cancer (Tumor).
Caput LII.	 Chapter LII (Roman numerals for 52).
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	 When Cancer is starting and you wish to stop it; then cauterize it with a ring-shaped cautery around it, as it rotates.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	 But the wise have said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	 I do not think that is correct; I fear it may burn, and I have seen it happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	 And it would be better to cauterize around it with a ring, as we have said; or with multiple cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Adubelati (boil).
Caput LIII.	 Head LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	 If someone has a boil and it is slow to mature or due to excess causing it, or because of old age and weak blood or due to time and a desire to hasten the maturation of the boil, then cauterize its circumference with small cauteries, many times.
Deinde dimitte eam.	 Then release it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	 For it will hasten with the maturation itself.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	 If you wish to perform a perforation of it with a cautery, then cauterize it with fire, whose shape is this:
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	 Place it in the middle of the Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be weakened from what follows, so that the course of the purgatives may be alleviated.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing a corroding disease.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter LIV.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	 A corrosive is not anything other than a corruption walking in a member and consuming it, just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	 If you see a corrosive in a place that can bear cautery with fire, then use much cautery, small and large nails, according to what suits the place where the corrosion is located.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	 Then cauterize it from every side until you root out the entire corruption, and there remains nothing of it deep within.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	 Then let it be for three days, and put sulfur pulverized with oil on the cauterized places, until all the scabs and all corruption are rooted out.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	 Then care for it with ointments that produce flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	 If you see that after three days, flesh is born with a healthy growth in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery on what remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	 A corrosive is sometimes treated with a sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	 The place of the cautery rises itself.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	 Nevertheless, cautery with fire is more expedient; and I have already said that the cauterization of it with a sharp medicine should be used in division; therefore, take it when you need it there.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing nails and warts.
Caput LV.	 Chapter LV.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	 This disease often occurs in the lower parts of the feet, and it is a thick, filtered one that injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	 And the cautery is indeed in two modes: cauterization with fire, and cauterization with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	 The quantity of the cautery with fire is such that it is similar to the concave tip of a vulture's feather: made from iron, its entirety should contain a nail; and its edges should be subtle.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	 Then place the heated (cautery) on the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	 Then, turn the hand with the cautery around the nail, until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail; and leave it for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	 Then, apply balm made of forest malve oil crushed with salt on it; and leave the balm over it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	 It will be uprooted from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of the place with a salve for healing flesh until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	 If they have not been converted and frequently occur on the surface of the body, particularly in hands and feet; then administer cauterization with hot water: it is to be noted that you should take a cannula made of copper, iron or vulture feather; and place it on the nail, or althea root.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	 Then throw a small amount of hot water into the cannula: hold your hand and turn it with slight pressure, so that the edge of the cannula presses on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail; let the weak one wait for about an hour under the pressure of hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	 Then release it, as the nail will be uprooted with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	 Do this to each one, until you have come upon all that are within the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	 Then take care of them after they have been uprooted, with the salve that generates flesh.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	 Method for Cauterizing in a Shaking Motion.
Caput LVI.	 De modo cauterizandi per rotundum in Trem
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	 When there occurs trembling due to cold in the nerve or from quartan fever or something else: then you should cauterize it with four or five cauteries on the dorsal spine, and a cautery between every spine, and on its chest, and above its stomach.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	 For trembling ceases with the cauterizing of oil, and hastens the health from cold illness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	 Method for Cauterizing Alabatrum (a type of porcelain).
Caput LVII.	 In quibusdam partibus corporis accidit, ut ne
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	 Sometimes in some parts of the body, alabatrum (porcelain) discharges foul matter, that is, pustules, which are produced by corrupted substances.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	 Therefore, when they appear, it is first necessary to cauterize them with a fine cautery over every head of the pustule with the myrtle wood, whose tip is ignited with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	 Or with the root of long-stemmed Aristolochia (an herb).
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	 Or with a lenticular cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	 And sometimes they are cauterized with ademenul (a type of metal), at the beginning of its expulsion according to this method; and they do not grow more; and the excess is broken, making them so, and it heals from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	 But it must be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 Method for Cauterizing when bleeding from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	 Quando accidit sanguis fluxu de arteria, ut
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	 Blood often flows from an artery that is cut near a wound, which happens externally or at the incision of boils, or cautery on a member, and similar to these; and it is difficult to separate it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 When it happens to someone, then hurry with your hand to the opening of the artery and place your index finger upon it: and tighten it much, until the blood is held under your finger so that nothing exits from there.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place in small oil lamps a few cauterizations, and blow on them until they are heated very much.
