Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one, either small or large, according to the wound and place where the artery is broken, and place the cautery upon the vein, after you remove your finger: and hold the cautery until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If the blood is ejected with the removal of the finger from the opening of the artery and the cautery is extinguished, then take another cautery quickly, from those which are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Therefore do not cease to do that with one after another until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And be careful, lest you burn the nerve which is there, and something evil happen to the patient through other malice.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is not possible to cut off [the blood]: especially because the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it is extracted, the ends contract and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or it is tied with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or they are placed upon it [the wound] medications that have the property of cutting off blood, and it is tied with a tight ligature using a bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 Whoever administers the amputation with a ligature and tightening with bandages, or with placing on them burning things and similar, does not completely heal him, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 If it happens to anyone that [the situation] occurs, and the physician is not present nor medicine available: then let him begin with the positioning of the index finger over the opening of the vein as we have said, and with a very tight constriction until the blood is blocked from above the wound, and on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 And let the finger not be removed, from above it with cold water of intense coldness always, until the blood freezes and thickens, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 And meanwhile let him consider what he needs from a cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 Part of the First Ends Here.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 Chapter on Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds and Similar Matters.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 We have already said in Chapter One, every sickness in which it is suitable to burn with cautery and burning medicine, its occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And there I placed the chapters from head to foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 And I shall proceed in this chapter along the same path, to alleviate the person seeking what he seeks.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before I begin that, my sons should remember what is in this chapter from the fear which is in Chapter One on Cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And because of that it is necessary to be more careful, since in the operation which is in this chapter, evacuation with blood frequently occurs, with which life stands at the opening of a vein or incision on an abscess or exit wound, or treatment of wounds, or extraction of arrows, or incision on stones and their similar: from all of which are associated tremor, fear, and in many of them death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 And I warn you, lest it fall upon you that wherein is hesitation, for sometimes they fall upon you in this art as do men with their weaknesses.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 For there is one who gets angry with his illness, and death is easy for him; because of the vehemence he finds from his weakness and the length of his wickedness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 And when it is with fear, this signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 And there is one who offers you the remedy and promises healing to you, hoping for health; but his disease is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 Therefore it is not fitting that you should agree with him who comes to you of such kind.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 Let your caution be stronger than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 And do not presume anything concerning that, unless after certain knowledge, which is proven to you by a praiseworthy sequence.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 And use in the healing of all your sick, prognostication and indication concerning that to which it is fitting for safety.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 For there is help to you in that concerning the acquiring of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 May God, O son, inspire you with His intelligence, and not remove from you the direction and inspiration; for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 And I myself have arranged this Chapter by dividing it into sections, according to what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from neck to feet; so that you may be relieved of that which you seek from him, and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 Chapter on the healing of water that accumulates in children's heads.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 Know that this weakness frequently occurs in boys during childbirth: or when the midwife tightens the boy's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 It also sometimes happens for reasons that are unknown.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 And indeed, I have not seen this illness in anyone other than boys; and for everyone that I saw of them, death followed immediately; therefore, it seemed to me that I should abandon the operation on this matter.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 And indeed, I saw a boy whose head was filled with water and who swelled up in every day until he could no longer sit upon himself because of the size of his head; and the wetness increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 This moisture, indeed, may accumulate between skin and bone; or it may accumulate beneath the cheekbone.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 And the operation on this matter, if there is moisture between skin and bone, and an abscess is small, then it is necessary to make a longitudinal split in the middle of the head, and let the width of the split be as two knuckles, until the moisture drains out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of a trephination (spatulum).
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 If therefore the moisture has increased more and the abscess is larger, then place these two splits according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if the moisture is beneath the bone and there is a sign that you see of the head's openings widened from all sides; and water comes out when you press it with your hand towards the inside and it does not hide from you; then make three splits in the middle of the head according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after the incision, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then suture the splits with cloth and lint.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then anoint it above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then loosen the sutures, take care of the wound with poultices, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 Do not let go of tying the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 Feed the sick person with dry food containing little moisture until the member is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 Another method of cutting is to consider where the size of the abscess appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Whenever it is more in the head, or in the forehead, or in the right, or in the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore ascend with incision where it appears to you an abscess and filling of water: and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And observe, do not cut an artery, and may the flow of blood occur, and the sick one dies from that flow with evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 Chapter on the incision of arteries that are behind the ears.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When someone gets cataracts on the eyes or on the chest, and it has become chronic and medical treatment does not help: then, more effective is the final treatment in him, incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore, when you wish to cut them (the arteries), it is necessary that the sick person shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then scrape the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let the sick person tighten his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then consider where the vein pulsates.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And the places on both sides are places that are depressed behind the ears and are rarely hidden except in some men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark both with hot wax: and cut each one with a spatula on both sides of the head, the incision reaching the bone; and let it be done all around the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if you wish, insert a spatula under the artery and cut it towards the top with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 Let the length of the incision be as long as two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 For when the vein is cut, blood comes out with a pulsating flow, which jumps to the internal parts with frequent leaps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 If, however, the artery does not appear to the sense (touch), then it is necessary that measurements be taken from the ear for the space of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark with hot wax and cut up to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And what must be released from the blood is 6 ounces (or fluid drachms), and perhaps you will release more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 All this must be done according to the quantity that appears to you from the strength of the sick person and the filling of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then consider for a wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 If there remains some flesh near the bone in the wound, then cut it so that no hot abscess occurs; then tie up the wound with linen rags.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with an ointment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 On the extraction of arteries, which are in the temples.
Caput III.	 Third Head.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When an old hemicrania or sharp catarrh occurs in a man due to acrimonious humidities and warmth in the temples, or an old soda, violent, and similar things: and it is treated with modes of curative medicine, but that does not help; then we have experienced extractions of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have said.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 And the method of operation in their extraction is that a weak person removes hairs which are in the temples, and intends towards the visible artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 Indeed, it is shown to you by its pulse, and it is rarely hidden except in a few men, or by violence of cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If it is hidden to you, then a weak person should tighten his head with any cloth of his, and then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or apply warmth to the place with hot water, until it appears to you in a manifest appearance.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take the probe that I made earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then scrape the skin with it easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then thrust into it a hook and draw it out upward until you draw it out of the skin, and make it emerge from all sides from the layers beneath it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 If, however, the artery is fine: then envelop it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut off from it a portion according to the length which its ends will extend and contract, so that there is no bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 For if it is not cut and not separated, the blood does not rise deeply.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then empty out six ounces of blood, up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large: then it should be tied in two places with a double thread, strong, of silk; or with threads of alum, so that decay does not occur to it before the wound heals and there is bleeding.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut the redundancy which is between two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do that at that hour or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a sharp-pointed cautery; until its ends are cut through and it remains in place for the same work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 It is a better operation, unless if he is weak and has fever, or is of cold constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because the cautery is made from those things that help to stop moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the extraction of arteries, the place should be filled with boiled old linen; and small, well-made fleas should be placed upon it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after the dissolution, it shall be treated with dry medications that cause flesh to grow and with linen, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If there happens to be bleeding from an artery while you are working, then go quickly to cut it with a cautery or fill the place with wax; and press your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 If none of those is present to you, then place your finger on the place until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 Anoint the place with water of intense cold, until the pain subsides and it is squeezed as required.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And from that which is easier and simpler to extract an artery, it is to cauterize the vein with this cautery having two sharp points; and let the sharpness of the two points be similar to a needle.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 However they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 Because if they are as sharp as two knives, coldness is required for both; and they do not cut the flesh swiftly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Since therefore there is some thickness in them, heat of fire is required within them; and the flesh is cut swiftly with this operation, which is better than any operation, and easier, and simpler.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two knives be of the size of a finger's thickness, after you mark two places with wax: and place both very hot ones, until they reach the bone, and cut through veins in two places: so that what is between its extremities may come out.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 They are not fully consolidated with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 Chapter on the treatment of acute and frequent tear ducts from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When tears are frequent and there is a channel for them from the veins on the exterior of the skull: and no remedy for them with medicines confers anything in this condition, and you see the face of the sick person becoming red, and feels walking in the forehead, as ants walk: and his eyes are weakened, moist, so that the hair of their eyelashes has already been corroded by corrosion: and his eyelids have become hot from the acuteness of tears: then ancients resorted to this treatment for them, and called it a cure, with a sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And it is that you command the sick person to shave the hair on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then cut three fissures in the forehead that are equal in length to the forehead: and let the length of the fissure be like two fingers, and let one fissure be in the middle of the forehead equal to the length of the nose, and the second near the movement of the arms, and the third on the other side: and be careful not to cut the arteries that are in the sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two jaws, and let the entire incision space be the size of three connected fingers: and have a piece of prepared sponge or dried cloth with which you can squeeze blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert a bistoury with two sharp ends, whose shape follows next.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the first incision, which is from the temporal part, to the second incision: and scrape off the skin that is between the two incisions, with a curette (sifac), which is on the bone of the forehead.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then make it also from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then remove this bistoury and insert another tool called a sharp knife (cultellare), blunt on one side, not sharp on the other side, into the first incision.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And place the sharp side towards the attached flesh with skin, and the blunt side towards the bone; push it in until it reaches the middle split, and cut off all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes; except for the incision which extends as far as the visible part of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then make it to the other split.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And when an equal amount of blood flows out, squeeze the areas from the clots of congealed blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then place linen from an old cloth into each split and put over them small pieces soaked in wine, oil or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And observe that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 And on the third day loosen the suture and administer a large amount of decoction with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of it with a basilico ointment and the rest that are used to heal wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 Chapter on treating sharp tears and catarrhs of the eyes, from the inside of the head.
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone gets sharp, intense, continuous catarrhs; you see their eyes are sunken, small, and their appearance is already weakened; and the eyelids are ulcerated, hairs fall out, and there is intense pain deep in the head, aggravating and causing sneezing; then take from among these symptoms what does not come from mucus or catarrhs unless they come from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 A better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 And it should be ordered to shave the sick one's forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make one incision in the middle of the forehead or slightly to one side, and begin the cut from the left temple to the right temple, and let the cut go as far as the bone; and move your hand away from the temples that move during chewing, until when the bone is exposed; then dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate the gap between the two lips of the wound using warm old cloth or linen irons.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then press down with pledgets and soak the pledgets with wine and oil to avoid a hot abscess.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you release it and see that the abscess is starting to subside, then you should cut the bone until flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then treat the wound with a drying regimen to promote growth of flesh; as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, prepare an ointment from them and apply it for the growth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 [Section title: Treatment of Ear Wounds]
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something resembling a stone such as iron and wood; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is liquid, such as water, vinegar, and similar things; or it is an animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 When a stone falls into the ear or anything resembling a stone that does not grow within the ear, expose only the ear: if you see a stone, then pour something from violated oil or sisamo into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer the extraction of it, and make him sneeze with a snuff, and close the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you place around the ear fragments from cloths or wool, and stretch the ear towards the upper part.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 This treatment is repeated many times.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not come out, then administer the extraction with Geista, that is, subtly cooked Pizigarolis [a type of medicine]: its shape is as follows.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 Therefore, if it comes out with Geista, this is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 If not, then administer the extraction with a fine blind hook, only a few times.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 If it does not come out through that [the blind hook], then make a tube from brass, and insert the end of the tube into the ear opening many times, and close what is around the tube with wax softened with oil, so that there is no way for air to pass except through the tube: then draw it out with your strong pull.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 This treatment is repeated many times.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 If it does not come out in this way: then take some helkalimbat or vinegar, that is, gluten prepared for catching birds, a small amount of it: and place it at the end of the radius after you have placed it accurately over it: then insert it into the ear opening with ease, after you have removed the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 If it does not exit as we have described, then hurry to cut, before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 The method of incision is to use a lancet on the weakened first in the head region: and draw out from the blood according to its virtue's measure.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the patient sit with his hands on his lap, and turn his ear upward, and make a small incision at the base of the ear in its fatty part at its depressed place: and let the incision be crescent-shaped, until you reach the stone: then remove it along with it, which is possible for you using your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then make the incision from your side quickly and carefully, until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 If what falls into the ear is one of the grains that grow and swell, then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 But if it does not obey you to exit, then take a fine, thin forceps according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And administer with it the removal of that species from the grains which fall into the ear, and do not do this when you think that the grain is already moistened by the ear's moisture, until you put many fragments on it: then remove it with tweezers, or with a fine hook, or with suction, as we have said, since its removal will be eased.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 In water that enters the ear, it is necessary for the patient to sneeze with his nose pinched in first: and already fill his ear with some cooked old solution: and there lies on it the ear where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 If it exits through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if it does not: then take many small, soft, warm stones according to the length of a finger, and heat them slightly with fire, and make the patient insert one from them into his ear's opening: and sprinkle some salt on his foot from that part, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Therefore, it should not cease to be done with a stone and stone, until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 And now water comes out in such a way that you take one from parchment or reed, and insert one end into the ear; and burn the other end with fire until it is burned much of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then take another reed and do the same thing many times until all the water comes out; and draw it out with a cannula as was said before in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 In the extraction of an animal entering it [the ear], if it is of small body, like a louse, and similar to what was said in the division [of animals], take care of it as I have said.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 But if it is of large body, which appears to sense, then administer the extraction of it with forceps and with hooks; and its substance is easier for all who hold in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 In the extraction of a worm generated in the ear, when you care for it with what was said in the division, and in the treatment of distillations, and your care does not help; then it is necessary that you look at the ear in sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 If therefore something appears from worms there [in the ear], then draw it out with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula whose shape is narrow below and wide above; and insert the thin end into the ear according to the amount that the weak one [patient] can tolerate; then draw it out with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 But if they do not obey you to come out, then circle the ear with seeds of poppy wrapped in a cannula as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 What if they do not come out with what was said: then administer the distillations which the ancients have already known for the destruction of worms; and you will find it in the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 And let your flow (be) from which you pour oil and medications into the ear with this instrument, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 As you see make it from silver or bronze, below narrow and below it has a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 Therefore let the thing that is inside the concavity of the cannel be made from bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 And if you wish, take radish, and roll on its end with a decent rolling; then pour oil or juice, or whatever medicine you prefer into the cannula, and let it be in the ear; then insert the radish rod with the heated top, and press it with your hand evenly, until the oil is pushed out in the concavity of hearing, and the sick person feels it inside; and what is poured into the ear should already be slightly heated with fire; and take care that nothing which distills into it is very cold; for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 Chapter on the treatment of an auricular impaction (obstruction or blockage in the ear).
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 When certain infants are born from their mother's wombs not pierced (perforated).
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 And it also happens to some people that an obstruction occurs in the ear from a wound or flesh grown there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this obstruction sometimes occurs in the deep ear canal, which is not visible to the eye; and sometimes it happens near the outer ear canal, and it can be seen by the eye.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, the obstruction that occurs in the deep ear and is not within the reach of sight, is difficult to cure in many ways.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in the case that is visible to the eye, it is necessary to place the sick person's ear on the sun and observe it; then if you see the obstruction appear, open it with a delicate spatula, whose shape is as follows, with its end having a small notch, part of which is sharp; and the rest of the spatula should be two-edged so as not to harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 If therefore an abscess arises from the flesh in the ear: then hold it with a fine hook, and cut it out with great ease, until the whole flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 If therefore an abscess is deep within the ear: then take a fine and sharp probe, heat it slightly with fire: then insert it into the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If you then find that the abscess is accompanied by illness and hearing loss: attempt an opening of it with ease: but be careful not to injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place linen cloth of appropriate size according to the width of the opening you have made, wrapped in Egyptian ointment: do this for several days until you are certain that the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take linen cloth and immerse it in distilled water, sprinkle powdered chalk over it, and use it (to clean the wound).
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you see that the ear is discharging pus: then it is necessary to extract the linen cloth, and let another linen cloth be placed over it, which has been soaked in a cerotic ointment made with rose oil, until the hot pus settles: afterwards care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 If there is bleeding instead: immerse a sponge or cloth in cold water, and place it on the ear: use the rest of the treatment that stops the described bleeding in the section about distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 Chapter on the care of Althaea's (marsh-mallow) for the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter 8:
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 These are the Althelil [affections] that occur in the eyelids of the eyes, which are sometimes moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore, one should hold them with tweezers or with a hook and cut them at their roots with a spatula.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then place it on the location of the bite, crushed.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 If blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lenticular cautionery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And it is better to cauterize them after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 For often they recur when something remains at their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 Section on the care of the eyelids of the eyes (Grandin).
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 Often something happens in the eyelids that resembles a Grandio (Grandio) in its strength and hardness, and for this reason it is called Grandio; and it is an accumulation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid and the lower one.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 Therefore, the operation is to see if there is a Grandio proceeding from it that appears on the eyelid and moves to all parts, and its substance is easy to remove.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Then make an incision over it along its width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then scrape it off from all sides with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then hang it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 If its removal is not prepared for you unless after you make an incision into the eyelid a little, then it harms the weak one (patient).\]
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the incision is large: then gather it together with stitches; and take care of it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if it is small, there will be no harm from that.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 Ointment restores it and fills it up.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 And if a foreign body is turned towards the inner parts of the ear facing the internal surface, then turn the eyelid inversely, and hang the foreign body with a hook; besides this, you will need an incision, and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 If the eyelid is stretched out by an incision, it does not harm it in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then clean the eye after the incision of the foreign body with salt water; and take care of the place with it until the weak spot heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 Chapter on the Care of Axirnath (Eyelids)
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 The Axirnath is a growth that is generated in the upper eyelid tunic; it mostly occurs in children, and it weighs down their eyes, causing cataracts in the mornings, and they are unable to look at the light of the sun, because tears flow towards them, and on account of this, you can see them lying on their faces constantly, and sleeping on them, and their eyelids are always under the eyebrows, which have already swollen; and indeed, the appearance of Axirnath is visible to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel the Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 The method of operation for it is that the weak person should put his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 Then take a clean cloth and prepare linen within it, and make a circle out of the linen according to the size that contains the Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place it on top of it, and press it with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 Then find in the center of that moisture with a small spatula, and let the fissure not be larger than the one made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 You must find the entire skin until you reach Axirnath, for in many arrangements Axirnath proceeds from the fracture according to the shape of a white plum's pit.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Draw it out with a cloth that you have dipped between your fingers to the outside: and you roll your hand left and right until it is dispersed: and take care not to add to the fracture, so as not to reach the spatumelas with a lancet at the eye, and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 If, however, Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fracture, you shall gently add into the fracture until Axirnath appears.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then draw it out as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the site, and bind it with small stones.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And there are men who grind salt, and place it in the hollow of the fracture, so that it dissolves what remains of that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 If, however, a hot abscess occurs at the place, then take care of it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 Chapter on the methods of Ataxmir for the eye: when the eyelid becomes soft and weeps excessively as it should not.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs grow in the eyelids beyond the natural course of the hair, and they turn white: then they harm the eye, and cause various ailments such as constant tearing, softening of the eyelid, and clouding of the cornea until it causes the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 And Ataxmir for the eye is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 With sharp medicine, as stated in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 The blind man Ataxmir is cured by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 With reeds, as I shall say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 You should place the head of the sick man in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If it (the eyelid) is turned, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 And if not: insert the needle into it (the eyelid), where there is a thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread, and let that be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow: and draw the thread upward with the eyelid, and turn it up with a spatula.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with a probe inserted from the larger tear duct to the smaller tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then extract the thread, and place a small round piece of cotton or cloth under the eyelid: then mark (tattoo) the eyelid with a branding iron in the shape of a myrtle leaf (as a mark).
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, it must be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: since this is diversified among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 For there are those who require that it (the eyelid) be cut in proportion to its size, according to the part which is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then with the probe find above the two lines which you marked, and begin from the larger tear duct to the smaller tear duct, and let there be one incision near the natural hairs, as thick as a nail.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then insert the hook into one of the two corners of the skin (incision).
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then scrape it (the eyelid) entirely.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then sew together with fine wool and needle the two edges (of the incision), and remove the blood, and let that which overflows from the threads on the eyebrows adhere to it, if you wish to do so; and if not, do not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then release the suture and the threads for three or four days; afterwards take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, release the wound without suture, and care for it as it dries and contracts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid should be raised during sealing of the wound and its collection, but it will be better in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 This method of healing was taught by the ancient ones named Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 However, there is concern for the sick one in it, and it comes from a good operation, but there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And another method exists in Ataxmir: and it is to mark signs on the eyelid in a form similar to that of the leaf of the myrtle tree, as we have told before.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then raise the eyelid with three separated or grouped combs, according to the following shape, then cut off what is excessive with small scissors, according to this shape, with equal incisions.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 If it is not possible for you to hold the comb, and it does not match it: then take a needle with a thread, and insert it into the middle of the shape; and insert another thread near the larger tear duct, and another thread near the smaller tear duct; and tie threads between your fingers with equal tension.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then raise your hand equally with the same lever: and lift the skin where the spot is marked, as we have told before.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then join two lips of the wound with a suture: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 If an abscess occurs at your incision or your tear, but it: pack the abscess with wax and similar substances from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes it happens that the eyelashes also turn inwards.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore, you should use what I have said for this incision, but suture is more artificial for both of them.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 "On the treatment of Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 "It is as if you turn the eyelid and make an incision in the inner fissure, as I have told.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 "Then make two canines or two fine sticks whose length is the same as that of the eyelid and whose width is smaller than the width of a thumb, and you have already made an incision at the ends of both sides where you hold threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 "Then apply both together with delicacy to the excess part of the eyelid of the eye and press the two canines from both sides tightly, and release it for some days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 "For the tightened skin will die, become blackened, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 "If it does not happen quickly, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 "Then take care of it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 "When it has become solid, lift the eyelid and do not pluck hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 "And this is the form of two canines which you should make according to this shape and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 "On the pulling out of hairs sticking in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	 "Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 "The operation is to take a fine needle, insert a thread from silk into it gently,
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 "Then connect the ends and tie them with a very fine knot; let the length of the threads be one palm."\]
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 "Then make another thin thread called Alinxotati, place it under the first and tie the ends if you wish."\]
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 "Then the patient should place his head on your lap and position it near the sun so that the operation may be seen clearly; because this operation is delicate or minute.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 "Then insert the needle with Alinxotati into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you pull out the natural hair from above."\]
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then draw the needle above the ankle-bone: and insert the needle into the ankle-bone; if it is one, or two, or three, not more than that.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then draw your hand with it until the needle emerges with the ankle-bone at the eyelid together with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 If the ankle-bone is drawn and the needle does not emerge with it: draw the ankle-bone downward, with the thread you have made in it, until the ankle-bone comes out through the superior opening, and you see it with the eye: then draw the ankle-bone and the thread; take both out, and close the eye; and leave it closed for two or three days until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 If the hair is short, then join a long hair from the natural hairs and elevate it with it; or leave it as it is until it lengthens, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 Chapter on the care of the xiphacteral ulcer that occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Title XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this xiphacteral ulcer happens to the eye, it is called a leporina (rabbit-like sore).
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And this xiphacteral ulcer is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 An accidental xiphacteral ulcer arises from the consolidation of a wound, or incision, or cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 And the method of treatment is to make an incision in it (the ulcer), and to separate its lips, and to place a linen cloth between them and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 And it is not necessary to use things that dry and constrict (the ulcer) for its treatment; if you do so, the xiphacteral ulcer worsens rather than improves; instead, use softening things such as fenugreek; and embrocation with water in which althea has been cooked, linseed; and an unguent of dyaquilon that has been softened with some oil; and wrap it with a linen cloth, and treat it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 Thy treasure of care is to strive with all thy skill, that it may not become consolidated, according to the form which it originally had.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 This operation indeed, is but a correction of Alzharate, so that the form of the place returns not at all to what it was originally.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 § On the care of Alzharate that is made on the lower eyelid, and it is a swelling or contraction upward towards right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIIII.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This which is below, is what is truly called Alzharate.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 And the accidental one is made from a wound, or a fissure, or a cautery, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 And the method of operation in it is to take a needle with a double thread, and moisten it in flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal to the right lacrimal, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then extend the flesh upward with the needle, and cut it with a broad scalpel.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 If therefore the form of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, take radium and place it in the fissure, and turn the eyelid with it; and make two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let their ends be from the angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle; until when joined together, this figure is formed, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then remove that flesh by the amount of its sharp edge below, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then join the separated parts; or join it with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then care for them with what I said, with softening medications, and linens, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 If an alxatrati occurs from a fissure, whether by suturing or cauterizing, then it is necessary to examine the fissure flat under the eyelashes, as was done before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate the two lips with a linen cloth, as I have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 In summary, the treatment of alxatrari, whether it is above or below, is to perform the operation as described for preparing the alxatrari.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 For it is of many different forms: and the skilful craftsman prepares the intellect with whatever method is possible for him, until he restores the figure to its natural form or almost so, and himself who is sick, according to what suits him from the operation and the tools in various dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 Chapter on the adherence of the eyelid with the conjunctiva or the cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 Sometimes this consolidation occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid becomes consolidated with the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you insert the end of the radius beneath the eyelid and peel it upwards: or stretch it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a delicate spatula, which should not be sharp like a spatula's edge, but rather blunt somewhat: so as not to disturb the sick man during the operation, and remove the spatula, and harm the eye with its sharpness: and let your incision be as if you are scraping off the adhesion gently, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, the adhesion heals completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then pour saltwater into the eye and clean it with water: or distill it onto him from sulphur boiled with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a linen cloth: and place warm wool soaked in egg white over the eye: and use sulphur on the third day and with ointments until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 Chapter on the incision of the nail and protrusion of skin at the corner of the eye.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Or it is nerve-like and is similar to horn, subtle.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 Or it is not nerve-like, similar to the consistency of frozen white matter that when touched with iron or attempted to be picked up with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not adhere to it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And both types do not start unless from the larger tear duct, up to where it gradually reaches the eye, until it covers the vision, and prevents light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method of operation for its incision is: let the sick person place his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open his eyes, and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Gather a small nail with a pair of tongs and extend it upward.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	 Then take the awl, and insert a horse or cow hair into it; let it be threaded, slightly enlarge the tip of the awl, fix it in the middle of the nail, and pierce it with the awl, tie it with thread around the nail, and extend it upward. Scrape the side of the nail following the pupil as if you were pulling it out to the very end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	 Then cut the remaining part in the root of the lacrimal with a thin spatula, or with small forceps: and let the natural flesh of the lacrimal pass, so that there is not a continuous flow of tears from the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	 And sometimes an onyx is extended with a chisel alone; or with a file, as we said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	 Then it is to be scraped with a soft spatula, whose shape is this.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	 And beware, lest the spatula touches the horny sheath and there occurs a breakage, and the pupil is pierced.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then after the incision, throw into the eye something crushed salt, or made from alum and vinegar, and let it remain until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	 And then care for it as needed, until it is healed.
