Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 Form of a Rasp with a Convexity (concavity).
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 Form of Another Fine-Toothed Rasp.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 Form of Another Rasp with a Curved End.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 Form of a Small, Fine-Toothed Rasp.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 Form of a Rasp for Cutting Bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also the form of a Large Rasp.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 It is similar to a Drill and its end is like a Saw; it is used in many places when cutting bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 Form of a Rasp suitable for cutting the bone that has been bored out.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 The extremity of it (the limb) is a triangle, sharp-angled.
Fit ex Indi.	 It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And similarly, it is necessary that everything which we have said should be made from files, incisors, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 [Section heading: On the Incision of Extremities, and Bone Sawing]
Caput LXXXIX.	 Head LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 Rottenness occurs at the extremities, either from external causes or internal causes.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 If you have treated that corruption with medicinal remedies but it does not improve and you see that the corruption is spreading in a limb which does not respond to any treatment: then it is necessary to amputate that limb up to where the corruption stops, so that the weak one may pass through it from death or from the greater evil caused by loss of part of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign that this happens is that the limb turns black until it seems so: what fire has burned it or rot has occurred after turning black: until the corruption reaches that part of the limb which follows it and creeps throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Therefore approach it for amputation and similarly if the cause of corruption is a blow from some venomous creatures such as sea-scorpions, weasels, nettles, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If the corruption or blow occurs at the extremity of a finger: then amputate the finger and do not leave any space for the corruption to spread, so that it may not reach the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And similarly if it happens in the hand: then amputate it at the root of the wrist and do not leave any space for the corruption to spread until it reaches the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it invades it (the hand or arm), then amputate the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If however the corruption passes beyond the elbow and you see it: then there is death for the weak one.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And any treatment beyond that (the amputation) is a quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And similarly do the same for the foot when corruption invades a toe: then amputate it at one of the joints; and if it reaches the front part of the foot: then amputate the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it [the abscess] rises to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 If corruption [of the limb] has already reached the knee, then there is no skill in it, except for amputation, and leaving the sick to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 The method of cutting a member or sewing it is to tighten the ligament below where you wish to cut and tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And stretch one of the ministers [assistants] to the lower parts, and stretch another minister to the upper parts.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And you separate the flesh that is between two ligaments with a broad spatula until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then it is cut or sewn.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And it is necessary that you lay a flax cloth over all the parts and not touch the healthy place with the knife; and let an additional injury be added to the sickness, and let a hot abscess come out.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 If there is bleeding internally while you are working, then quickly cauterize the place or put some powders on top that absorb blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your care until it [the wound] is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded member with a suitable ligament and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you what happens to a man in his foot, the same thing that I have told you will happen.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 What happens is that there occurs blackness in the foot, similar to burning like fire; and corruption starts first with a toe until it covers the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 Therefore the man was ashamed of himself when he saw corruption occur in his limb with intense pain that he discovered from the pain and burning; and he cut it at the joint, and he healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long time had passed for him, the same corruption occurred in the index finger of his own hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 Therefore, it came to me, and I attempted to recover that excess with what I placed on his hand from the medicines after mutilation of his body; but it was not found, and it began to progress to another finger; until corruption started in the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 He called me to cut his hand; but I did not want it, hoping for a recovery of the excess [of fluid]; and I also feared death due to the incision of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Because the strength of the man was over his fall.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 After he had given up hope in me, he returned to his own land; and he came to me about that [incident], because he had hurried and cut off his whole hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I did not bring this narrative unless as aid for that which falls under the genus of this disease; and as signification, and according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 [Title: On the Treatment of Sinusitis, and the Quality of Enemas with Medicines.]
Caput XC.	 Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When an abscess occurs in some fleshy parts, and the space of the abscess continues until it makes a collection of pus; then it breaks or perforates, and what is inside the pus comes out, and leaves a hollow place as if it were a vessel; and the skin that is above it becomes thin like a cloth that has been softened; and it does not reach its final corruption, nor press on the bone, nor on the nerve, nor on the ligament; it deserves to be called Sinus; but it is not called Fistula; however, if the space continues until corruption presses into one of these organs, then it is called a Fistula, or a boil.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And its treatment is to cut the whole skin as it rolls out; and especially when it has been softened and made like a cloth; and trust that it will not stick because of its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 If you think that it adheres to the skin and does not follow by that ultimate corruption: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then treat it with a poultice; and it is, that you consider for the sinew.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 If it is large, and the pus that comes out of it has a foul smell: then poultice it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and zinc oxide mixed in equal parts, heated in a vessel until the medicine turns red and thickens to the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take what is needed from it: and dissolve it with water and honey, and poultice the sinew with it; and bind the opening of it, and leave the medicine in it for two hours' quantity.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then remove it with pressure: make this daily until the sinew is purified and the foul smell is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And when you are not able to use this medicine, poultice with water and ashes; and it is, that you take the ash of grape wood, or the ash from oak trees, and throw water over it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then cook it well, and poultice with it until you are confident that the sinew has been cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the patient is not able to bear the Egyptian medicine or water and ashes, then poultice it with water and honey, into which something from crushed zinc has already been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or poultice it with honey and wine mixed, since the property of honey is to cleanse and purify; and wine holds the sinew, especially when there is an excess of stiffness and dryness in wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you are certain that the corruption of the sinew has been removed, then poultice it with what causes flesh to grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And it is to be noted that from the plaster dyafinicon, you shall dissolve it with rose oil and stiptic wine, or you shall purge it with certain medicines and other unguents, whose properties I have written about in the treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the orifice of the Sinus is narrow and does not accept a cannula for cleansing, then expand it slightly with iron, or place within it a linen cloth rolled up in Egyptian ointment, or in Basilicon ointment until it expands.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the orifice is also wide, then approximate its lips with suture, and allow the amount in which the cleansing can enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the orifice from which pus flows is elevated towards the superior, then cut it at a lower place that is within it so that pus runs out below; since when pus is constricted in the depth of the Sinus, it prevents flesh from generating in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus below as you wish, then try to prepare a limb so that pus can run out from it with ease according to your preparation.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try not to retain anything of the pus at all in it; and take healing medicines that are placed on the sign, which suit your purpose.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 Spread them out on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 Let the linen cloth be of such size that there is communication throughout the whole Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then make a hole with scissors directly in the orifice of the Sinus, larger than the orifice of the Sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread a layer of soft ointment over another cloth, according to the size of the hole; and place it above it at a distance from the orifice of the Sinus so that the exit of pus from it is relieved; and do not remove the large cloth unless after several days in succession.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 He who is above the opening of the Sinus should be removed at all hours so that what accumulates in it due to pus may exit; and know, whether what flows from it is much or little, digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And again, consider the place of the Sinus itself, whether its master feels pain there or not, and whether there is an abscess there or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 Since your treatment is so extended and you see the material that exits from the opening of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus already adheres or approaches adhesion; then therefore dissolve it in the morning or on the third day; and when you dissolve the wound, then change the linen and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 If, however, pus flows out of the Sinus for a long time, do not despair of its adhesion, for healing is approaching; because there are some who have a slow generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are others who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 If, however, for many days an undigested pus flows out of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 Therefore, if the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its treatment prolonged; then add to the drying remedies, but let the doctors ensure that they are in substance moist and in effectiveness dry, such as ointment dyafinicon when superfluous addition is added from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the most remote treatment is that you receive ointment dyafinicon, which is dissolved with rose oil and shaken over it ancient wine equal in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then make it with this and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And now do the same with this action when you are not present ointment dyafinicon, honey, when you cook it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Receive myrrh, and aloes, and frankincense: grind it all, and pulverize it on honey while it is over fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then cover it with linen cloth and bind it over the bladder: and line it with honey that you have boiled, until it thickens; and sprinkle powdered spices over it, and place it on the linen cloth and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And at times, long aristolochia, celestial lily roots, and lily itself are administered: and the flour of herbs, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them in simple form or compound, grind them and sift the powder: and sprinkle it over the honey that I have mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 If the bladder prolongs and is not cured by this treatment: then know that there is corruption within it: or it already makes an impression on the bones, or in other hard members, or ligaments: then treat it with fistula cure, according to what has been mentioned before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 Section on panaritis and the scratching of the nails, and the addition of a digit incision, and section.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter CXI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Panaritis is an abscess that arises under the nail of the thumb or foot, and perhaps arises in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 If it prolongs and is neglected in its treatment, and is abscessed with hot abscessing: or it becomes corrupted and emits pus until it corrodes the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts it completely, and the corruption reaches the bone, until there is a foetid smell; and the end of the digit becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When you treat it, when you have done what I have said in division, and your treatment does not help: then it is necessary that you scrape off the entire superfluity that remains from the nail with iron.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 Indeed, cautery is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 If the bone is healthy and so is the nail, and there are empty additions of the nail that press the flesh towards the inside and begin to pierce it and injure it; then it is necessary that you place fine radium under the edge of the nail that pierces the flesh, and push it up; and cut the flesh easily, and put on top of what remains of the flesh from medicines that burn, corrosives, until it is removed entirely.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 If the corruption has already pressed into the bone, then it is necessary to cut that bone and remove it; for a rotten bone will never heal while it remains in there.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 If you see that corruption and decay are advancing on the finger, then cut it at a knuckle, as previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 If the nail should happen to be rubbed or struck and a very severe pain occurs, then it is necessary to use the phlebotome first on the weakened.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with an acute cross-cut of the spatula from above as desired.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And beware that the cut does not reach the flesh that is beneath the nail, for you will cause a very severe pain to arise above it and this will lead to an addition of flesh at the site.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then care for the place with something that alleviates the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 The finger added to certain human hands is possibly all flesh; and it may be that some of them have bones, and it may be that there is a nail in it: and some of them are born at the joint of the root, or its birthplace is in some knuckles of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 Therefore that which is born in certain knuckles of the finger does not move; and that which is born at the joint of the finger may possibly move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 Therefore its cutting is easy if it is all flesh.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 It is to cut it at the root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 But its care is difficult if its birthplace is at the joint of the root.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore refrain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 In that one which is born at the end of the finger at a knuckle, then it is necessary to cut the flesh with a round cut until the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then cut the bone with a saw that fits among those suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 However, the consolidation that occurs in fingers often happens multiple times either due to birth itself, i.e., being born with it, or from a wound consolidation, or burn by fire, and similar conditions.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, the consolidation should be removed until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place linen or cloth soaked in rose oil between them to prevent quick consolidation and separate them; or put a thin lead plate between them until the location is healed as required.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if consolidation occurs in some fingers with the palm, then remove that consolidation according to what is prepared and suitable for the member's shape.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 Chapter on the Fault of Incision.
Caput XCII.	 Chapter CXII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Wounds are swollen veins, thick, filled with melancholic fluids that occur in many parts of the body; and most commonly they occur in legs, especially in the legs of travelers and laborers, and those carrying heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore, it is necessary to administer a strong purge for the body at times due to black bile.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then, let the bloodletting of the patient be made on the basilic vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 The cure for them (swellings) with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One of them is, that they should be lanced and black blood be drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And the other method is, that a vein shall be opened up and all drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Cutting is done according to this method (lancing).
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 Pour a lot of hot water on the leg first, until thick, foul blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then bind the weak leg from its upper part of the hip to the lower part of the thigh with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein at one or two or three places in a wide cut.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then draw out the blood, that is, extract it with your hand from the lower part of the leg upward, and it is necessary for the leech to attend to the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail and draw out from the blood as much as you see is sufficient, and as much as the strength of the patient can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Afterward, bind it (the wound) and tell him to abstain from foods that cause black bile; and repeat the purge and bloodletting when the veins become filled, and this is harmful to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The drawing out (of pus) is done according to this method (opening a wound, draining it, then applying a poultice).
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 If the leg of the patient has many hairs, shave it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then introduce it into the bath, or apply embrocation to his limb with warm water until it turns red and veins appear; or exercise it with strong exercises if there is no bath available, until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then dry the skin directly on the vein incision along its length; or in the end part of it near the knee, or in the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with combs and scrape the vein from all sides until it becomes sensitive; at its appearance, as you see it turn red towards blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it has departed from the skin, you see it white like a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert radium under it until it rises and comes out of the skin; hang it with a blind comb, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then make another incision nearby that incision with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then scrape the skin from the top of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then remove it with radium as you did before and hang it with another comb as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then make another incision, or several incisions, if necessary.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then remove it and cut the last incision at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then extract the part that is above the incision.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 Do this until you have extracted it from the higher incision, or all the incisions, until it comes out entirely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 If it does not obey you to be extracted and removed; then insert a sharp needle with strong thread and tie it and extract it yourself; or insert radium under it and move your hand over all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful not to cut (it).
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it becomes very difficult for you to remove it and from that it causes harm to the sick person.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you have removed it completely: then place linen soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil, on the wound site, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If it is a vine (grapevine) with a twisted shape and coiled at parts, not as we have said in a straight manner: then you must make an incision over all its twisted parts and the coiling sites of it.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then hang it with hooks until you have pulled out the entire thing: and be careful not to cut any vein or wound during your incision; for it will be difficult for you to pull or extract it if you do.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Therefore, exercise caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The method of treating a vine (grapevine).
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The method for treating a blind boil.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Its scab is not like that of other boils, nor is it sharp-ended so as to pierce a vein; and it is rather large and flexible, soft; for if it were subtle, it would pierce the vein with its subtlety; on the contrary, its excessive size is superfluous, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 The method of extracting a leg vein.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in the warm lands of Egypt, as Azizgi said, and in the dry, hot, sandy areas with little vegetation, that is, where no herbs or trees grow.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 Its generation is indeed from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, as it happens in the bodies of snakes and roundworms (ascarids) and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 The sign of this vein's emergence is that it occurs when there is a severe inflammation of the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then let the area be bled.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 The vein starts to come out from that spot of bled area, like a root of plant or animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When it appears from that end, then it is necessary to wind around it a piece of lead, whose weight shall be one and a half drachms, up to two drachms and a knot; and let the hanging lead be released from the arm.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something comes out of it to the outside, wind it around with lead and knot it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it prolongs much, then cut a part of it and wind the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut its root before it comes out completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 Because if you cut [the ligature], it contracts and enters the flesh; causing an abscess to appear, a bad ulcer and pus.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it should be treated gently and slowly extracted until it comes out completely and nothing remains in the body; and from this vein there comes forth in some men what is of its length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has come to me, because the man has come out of twenty palms (i.e., 20 cm).
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If it is cut during your treatment, then insert a rod into its opening and perforate it with a long rod along with the body until all that is inside it from the matter comes out; and administer medication for decay of the place for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then care for it with treatment for abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or on the foot itself; and openings occur for it in several places, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Take care of it as we have said in the division, and with what has been previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 The ailment concerning worms generated beneath the skin is called Bouina.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This ailment is called Bouina in a certain land among us: because it often occurs in cows, and there is a small worm born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 It moves throughout the body, ascending and descending; and it is revealed to sensation during its movement from limb to limb, until it bursts at any place where it bursts through the skin, and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 Its generation is from the corruption of certain fluids.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 Just like worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms, occur in the abdomen.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 It is feared because of its mischief.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it moves within the body and rises to the head and arrives at a place, then perhaps it opens there and emerges, and destroys an eye; and this often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 Therefore, when one wishes to treat it and extract it, this is not done except during its movement and the appearance of it to sensation.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 Therefore, one must bind what is above it, and what is below it with a strong bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut on top of it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If it has penetrated into the flesh, and you do not find it; then apply a hot iron to the place until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 And the greater thing that is feared is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then bind under it with a good bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut on top of it, and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 It is necessary for the sick person to use self-cleanliness of his body, with medicines that dissolve foul, bad fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let them avoid food causing putrefaction to themselves.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 On Section for the Ailment of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This ailment is known in our land as Nakir: it is a pain that occurs in certain members, then it shifts from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I myself have already seen it, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was called to a sick woman in some villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And she extended her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after staying for an hour, I saw the swelling moving with a worm-like motion, quickly ascending to her shoulder as if quicksilver flows from one place to another.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 Therefore the pain left that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then she sat for an hour, and it ran throughout her body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then she told me that she was revolving in her entire body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 I marveled at the swiftness of its shifting from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And I myself had never seen this ailment with my eyes before in such a way as now.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 Yet I saw many who found pain shifting from member to member: I did not see it as I did in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that it was anything else than because the woman was from those who are from the villages of the detected veins: hence it appears that the swelling was shifted.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that it not appear according to this reasoning in those who are delicate and moist bodies of concealed veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 When therefore you wish for the cure of it and the patient feels that pain: then if it appears to you with the eye, as we said, then tighten above it, quickly beneath it; cut above it until that constrained wind escapes; cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If you do not see it with your eyes: then cure it by excision of the body and with that which expels winds, and crush them with foul-smelling pills and pills of turpentine, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 Chapter on the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter XCVII.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are classified according to their types and according to the places where they fall on the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 The diversity of arrows is as follows: because there are some that have large points and small ones; concave or blunt.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And there are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And those with tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And those with stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 Those that fall on the limbs are twofold according to mode.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 Or limbs are from the hollow members like brain, heart, liver, lung, kidney, intestines, bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When an arrow falls into one of these hollow members and you see signs of death as I am about to tell you, then it is necessary to seek the extraction of that arrow from them because death follows him who has it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when you do not see these bad signs and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it yourself and heal the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 From the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates the bone, and exits on the top of the brain, are: because from this occur soda vomiting, scotoma, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasm, confusion of intellect, and cholera vomit.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And perhaps speech is cut off and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And from the wound place comes out whiteness similar to plaster.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And out of it comes forth like a watery flesh-like substance.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment and remove the arrow if it does not come out by itself.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are as follows: that it is near the left nipple; and it feels as if it is fixed in a solid rather than in a soft thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps there is motion similar to the pulse movement, and blood runs out from the wound in black color.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 It follows this coldness of limbs, and a cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Know therefore that death approaches without doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 And the sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is as follows: foamy blood comes out from the wound; and containers that follow the neck are to be removed, and the complexion of the ill person changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And it breathes out a large, high breath and seeks cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls into the abdomen, which is in the chest; then it is near the small ribs; and a great panting with strong pain occurs along with sighing, and all limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if the arrow falls into the abdomen and lodges there, something like feces comes out from the wound or pus, or an already disrupted intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore, there is no hope for his cure, nor for removing the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 And if the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out; and something proceeds from it to outside, and the pain is stronger over the sick person; then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The remaining limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, spatula, aid, dorsal spondiles, crossbar, hip, leg and similar members are to be healed according to several dispositions: when the arrow does not hit an artery or a nerve; and the arrow is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you what I saw of these arrows, that you may know by it concerning your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 It is, because a man had fallen an arrow into his tear duct of the eye, at the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore I extracted it myself from the other side, under the ear fat of him; and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen on him under the lower eyelid of his eye; and the arrow was already hidden, and I only obtained a small part of it, which adhered to the wood of it; and the arrow was large among the arrows of the Turks, with a soft iron, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore the Jew was healed, and no harm came to his eye as a result.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 And it was an Arabian arrow, and he has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 Therefore I cut it across in two; and it was already immersed in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 I therefore sharpened myself with it, until I extracted it; and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I extracted another arrow from a man who had fallen it on his abdomen; and we thought that he would die as a result of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed without anything changing with regard to him in his treatment, I therefore cut across the arrow; and I sharpened myself on it, and extracted it; and he was healed, and no harm came to him as a result.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man to whom an arrow fell upon his back, and the wound was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 And I saw a woman to whom an arrow fell into her belly, and the wound was healed over it, and the arrow remained within her; and no change occurred in her condition from her disposition, and the woman did not find any harm to herself in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 And I saw another man to whom an arrow fell on his face: and the wound was healed, and remained, not causing him much pain; and similar things happened many times.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 And I extracted an arrow from a prince of the king that had fallen on his nose, which had already turned slightly to the right side; and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 Therefore, I was called for its treatment after the loss of the arrow up to three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 Therefore, I found the wound of the arrow to be very constricted.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 Therefore, I probed it with a delicate probe, and did not feel it; but he himself found a puncture and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore, I hoped that the puncture was at the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I then covered the spot with a plaster containing an attractive and digestive agent, trusting that the spot would open up, and I would see the sign of the arrow so that I could cut it; but this did not happen in the place that indicated that the arrow had struck.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 Therefore, I kept the plaster on him for many days; but it did not happen, and the wound became more and more consolidated; and he remained weak from its extraction until he felt the arrow one day within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me that (it is).
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I then applied sharp and corrosive medicine to the wound for many days until it opened; when I probed it, I felt a subtle tip of the arrow adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added through the opening of the wound a sharp medicine until the arrow tip appeared visibly to us; and it passed by me during about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 Then when the wound was swollen, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not obey to come out; then I did not cease sharpening, and working on it with means of ingenuity, until one day with well-made forceps, according to the form they would take at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I healed the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed physicians judge that cartilage of the nose cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore healed it, and the wound was consolidated, and became healthy again in a strong health; nothing harmed him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you the quality of extracting some arrows; that you may place this rule and meaning on what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Since the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended with the narrative; nor does that book contain it, and the wise craftsman compares little with much; and with what is present, regarding what is absent; and he finds a new operation, and a new tool among descents of things foreign to this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I therefore say that arrows do not come out from the members on which they are fixed, unless in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by attraction from the place from where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Opposite part of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which comes forth where it entered is either an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place and is both attracted and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 If it does not obey to exit at the time it falls: then it is necessary that you let it be for some days until the flesh around it decomposes and the attraction disappears and its exit takes place.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly if it is fixed in a bone and does not obey to exit, then let it be also for some days; and move and shake it every day until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 If it does not obey to exit after several days, then it is necessary that you pierce around the arrow on the same bone from every side with a fine chisel in order to make the arrow swell up.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then attract it and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has reached one of the ventricles of the brain and symptoms such as those mentioned before appear: then refrain from pulling out the arrow and let it be until it becomes equal with its position after several days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if the arrow has reached the heart, death does not extend to it.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed except in a bone only and does not penetrate up to the heart; and it remains weak for some days and does not suffer from any of the symptoms mentioned earlier: then apply skill in pulling out the arrow and its attraction.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 If it is very firmly fixed and does not obey to your pulling out: then apply a chisel around the arrow as I told you earlier; then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow is already concealed in a part of the body and hidden from sensation; then seek it with probing.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If however you feel it (the part to be operated), then draw it out with certain instruments suitable for its drawing out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot go over it (the arrow) due to the narrowness of the wound and the depth of the arrowhead; and there is no bone, nerve or vein there: then pierce it (the arrow), until the wound expands so that the arrow can be pulled out.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If there are ears attached to it (the arrow), then free the fixed flesh from all sides, in every way you can; and the instruments, if it cannot be moved by simple pulling on the flesh of the ears, and by twisting them, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And you, when you perform the extraction of an arrow, wherever it is located: then use twisting with your hand, together with pliers in all directions, until you make it come out; and gently, with the utmost subtlety, so as not to break the arrow, and its drawing out becomes difficult for you, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot move it within an hour: then leave it for several days, until what is around it (the wound) becomes putrid.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then return to it (the arrow): the dressing (tunic) will heal by itself. If however a flow of blood opposes you: then administer what we have said in its treatment as described in its chapter; and take care to avoid cutting any vein, nerve or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And apply all means of pulling out the arrow in every way possible for you; and let it be with ease, calmness, slowness or firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when you pull out the arrow, it be weakened in the same way as it was at the moment of the arrow's wounding.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more helpful (to do so).
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If it is not possible for you [to perform the operation], then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 An arrow that emerges from the opposite part of another [body], or already proceeds to the outside: or makes a swelling at the tip of the arrow by sensation on the upper part of the skin near it, and you see it protruding: then cut above it, and let the incision be according to the quantity that will be able to grasp tweezers in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw it out; for it will become easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If it is held in the bone, then turn your hand according to its roundness until the arrow presses into the bone and expands itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: let it be for some days; then try again until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the shaft of the arrow is in it [the wound], then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 If the shaft has fallen out and you wish to give a pushing force: then insert a concave instrument into it so that it enters the concavity of the arrowhead; then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If the arrow is concave, then push it out with the instrument inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 For the arrow is held by that [thing].
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to excavate all the flesh where the poison is; if it is possible for you [to do so].
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then treat it with that which suits for that purpose.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the arrow falls into the chest, or into the abdomen, or into the bladder, or into the side [of the body] and is close to that which you touch with your hand, and it is possible for you to make an incision above it: then make an incision, and avoid cutting a vein, or a nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then look at your wound and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And here is the shape of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The ends should be like a bird's beak, made of iron; when they grasp an arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And various shapes are made from them, large, small, and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow, its smallness or largeness, and the size and narrowness of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The shape of a plunger is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 The shape of a deaf-plunger is spherical.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the shape of a deaf-plunger like a radius, so that its entrance may be applied to a concave arrowhead and it may be pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The end of the concave plunger is concave like a bird's feather; so that its entrance may be applied to the arrowhead and it may be pushed into it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 Chapter on venesection (bloodletting).
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter LXVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 Veins for bleeding, whose custom runs in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 From the head there are sixteen: two Pulsating Veins, which are behind the ears, called Two Herbs: and two Arteries, appearing in both temples: and two Veins, which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, called Looking-at: and Prepared Vein in the middle of the forehead: and a Vein at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two Jugular Veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 The veins which are bled in the arms are five in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is the Cephalic, and it is from the side of the woods; and the people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 And the Black one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And there is a Middle vein, and it is made of the branch of the Basilic, and the branch of the Cephalic; and the people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And the Basilic, and it is placed on the domestic side; and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And the people call it the vein of the abdomen.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And the Sinew of the arm, and it is placed on the elbow; and that is the one which is bled, and it is the one which appears above the thumb in a clear manner.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And the Saluatella: and it is the vein that is between the ankle and the toe; and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and foot, there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 One of them is a curvature under the nail on the side of the little finger.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 The second one is the saphenous vein, and its place is at the heel by the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And the vein of Naessa: and its place is at the heel on the outer side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And in another limb, there are three veins like these [veins].
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 Chapter on phlebotomy of two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 However, phlebotomy of the two veins that are after the ears, is beneficial for old catarrhs, and headache, and scrofula, and ancient evil ulcers on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of phlebotomy is as I have said [explained].
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 It is to shave the head of the sick man, and rub his neck in the place of the two veins with a rough cloth for good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then, the sick man tightens his neck with an ointment until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 And their places are behind the ears in two depressed places on the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Therefore, seek them with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, mark it with a hot iron [branding].
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take the lancet for phlebotomy, and it is called Incisor [cutter].\]
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then insert it [the lancet] under the vein into the flesh until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then pull your hand with the vein and skin upward, and cut the vein with an incising incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be the size of two joined fingers or approximately that, and make as much blood come out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then tie it [the wound] with threads, and let it heal.
