And I have never encountered anything good in it entirely, and I have not acquired from it that which I have acquired except due to the length of the reading of ancient books, and my zeal for understanding them, until I extracted the knowledge of it from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I adhered through experiment and study over the course of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 I have now described for you everything that my knowledge contains on the subject of this Chapter: and above what my experiment has passed, after I have abridged it for you, and freed it from occupation and length, and abridged it to a conclusion, and showed it to a conclusion: and I have formed many shapes in it from the shapes of instruments which are used therein, since it is a matter of addition, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and collections of cases of bone fractures, from those of which a prior understanding is necessary before we begin the recollection of the broken members, and of different ones, if of any one in particular.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this Chapter the main points and chapters to which one must be directed first in his understanding for the craftsman concerning their truth: namely, so that you and those who are quick may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 Therefore, I say that when a fracture or dislocation or twisting or accident occurs to someone, it is necessary first to hasten to bleed him and to loosen him, or both at the same time: unless something prohibits this, such as weakness of strength: or he is a child who has had one of these things, or an elderly person in decline: or it is a time of violent heat, or violent cold extremely.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, onions, and beans; and forbid wine, fat meats, and to be filled with foods and any food that fills veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until he is secure from a hot aposteme and no longer fears the issue of matter to the limb; then let the sick person return to his own regimen first with which his custom was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the fractured bone begins to heal, then it is necessary for the sick person to eat nutritious foods in large amounts, thick, heavy, with viscosity; such as foods made from cooked wheat with water, rice, heads and feet of animals, intestines of sheep, eggs, fresh fish, thick wine and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 With this regimen, the healing of the fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And you should know that fractured bones, when they are in men who are in the first old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be held together and consolidated according to their nature always, due to drying of their limbs; and they consolidate and hold together what are from those bones at the end of softness, like the bones of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 However, nature connects something similar to gluten around the fractured bone from all sides, in which there is thickness, by which it adheres and tightens it until they consolidate with each other, and bind together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not forbid something from its operations; and for this reason it is necessary that you put the nutriment of the sick person in foods that are thick, viscous, and heavy, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the difference of the members; for a fracture of the limb is different from a fracture of the skull bone; and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the back bone; and similarly all other members are different one from another; and I come with the reminder of every type of fracture explained in its own chapter distinguished from the others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The types of fractures differ among themselves as well.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 For a fracture is sometimes curved, except that studs occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes a fracture is along the length of the bone; and there are fractures which are studs (astellae), that is, studs, and additions proceeding, such as in a reed when it is sharpened with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not proceeding; and there is a fracture with wound and rupture in the head; and there is a fracture of a small crack.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every type has its art or specific tool in the restoration of it, according to which its reminder will come, distinguished in their respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which the bone fracture is known, its curvature and protuberance appears; and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore no curvature appears in the place, nor a sound to your touch when you touch the bone with movement, nor does it have a great pain; then there is no fracture there, but it may be that there is a curvature or a small crack; therefore, you should not move it with your hand and compression at all; rather, lay medicines upon it, whose reminder comes after that which suits the place; then compress it with a fine ligature.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when a place bows and is divided into two, excepting what happens to it in the form of pus, yet every part is removed from its comparison: then it is necessary for you to begin from your hour for its correction, equalizing it before hot suppuration occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If hot suppuration occurs, then leave it for some days until the pus subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then equalize it according to whatever method is possible with gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration of this, and its equalization, is easier than the bone, in which pus occurs.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tie it up according to your recollection of it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If in a bone pus occurs, then the extension of this broken member is necessary from two parts, if it be a hand or foot; or with your hand, if the member be small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 Let your position be such that you place the member on an equal location according to its natural shape, until the parts of the broken member are extended; then try with all skill and in whatever way you can to make the additions return to their places, and in the best way possible at their locations: and beware according to your strength, so that pain or injury does not occur due to your operation; and try according to your strength to apply one of two bones together with its companion, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 It is necessary in that hour for you to attempt and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If you see something different there, correct it and equalize it according to the quantity of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of vigorous extension and strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 They often cause a hot abscess or contraction in a limb by their surgery, as we have seen it many times from their surgeries.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then attach [something] after the equalization, and a proper surgical procedure, and a tightening of that limb, and calmness, and peace: and warn the patient regarding it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And make him beware, not to move himself during the hour of his watch, and sleep, at the time of rotation, and agitation, and at the time of hunger, and all movements, in the utmost strength of his power.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And that he beware, so that the position of the limb is not followed by pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 Since when he feels pain or injury in the position of the limb, then it is necessary that he be moved to another position which does not cause pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And beware with him so that his position is equal and straight, so that no tortuosity occurs in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of the tightening of the broken limb is as I have told.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that broken limbs are differentiated according to their smallness, their size, and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those which are small, such as the arm, finger, spade, and similar things, then it is necessary that there be a soft, fine wrapping of cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 And those which are large, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary that there be a wide, hard wrapping in them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Since a wide bandage connects a large limb and tightens it from all sides with an equal tightening, so that no spot is entered by it.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then after your evacuation, place the appropriate lining on it from the equalization, in soft wool over the location of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to roll the ligament over the place of the fracture with three or four rolls, according to what the limb deserves; and tighten your hand slightly with the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go to the upper part from the place of the fracture and tighten less than your previous tightening with which you tightened the fractured place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then extend yourself with the roll from the place of the fracture a little, and soften the tightening gradually until you take a large amount from the healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another piece of gauze, and roll it again over the fractured place with rolls.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Then go to the lower part from the fracture with the roll.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your operation be in the tightening of the rolling and its softening, according to what we said in the first roll.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the rolls of soft wool or cloth, which equalizes the curvature if there is a curvature in it; and if not, do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then roll over another piece of gauze.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place stars evenly spaced immediately over these rolls, if there is no swelling or hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is swelling or an abscess: then place it on that which sits on the abscess, and remove the swelling; and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then tighten the stars over it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 The stars should be made from the middle parts of a wide reed, shaved and skillfully formed; or they should be made of wood from which cribra are made, which are made from pine, yew, palm branches, or calingi; and the size of all the stars should be according to this shape and this same form.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, the star that is placed over the suture should be a little thicker and wider than the other stars; and the length of the star should be according to the size and smallness of the member.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind on top of the star with another plaster, according to the first binding's tightness.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind well with thread, as we said concerning binding; and it is that your binding over the place of the fracture should be more than the fracture itself; and the farther away from the fracture it becomes, the less the binding should be.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 And it is necessary that the threads are of medium size and fineness, and they are made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 For if the threads are thick, as I have seen from the work of foolish men placing their threads from twisted cords of linen, it is a great error; because the binding falls with them beyond quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And again, very thin threads do not agree; for you will not obtain what you desire through the binding with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not necessary that there be less than a finger's breadth between stars.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the sick man is harmed by the ends of the stars after binding in healthy places: then put under them from soft wool or carded wool until nothing is harmed from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a fracture with a wound, and a tear occurs in the skin, I will come with its discussion in the second chapter according to its particularity.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken member should be bound with stars from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 For when the member is large, it is not necessary to put stars on top of it unless after five days or seven or more, according to your safety from the occurrence of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 And this is the method of plasters which the ancients used to restore them, which are placed on a fracture and a luxation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ The common method of emplaster shortened, restoring a fracture, suitable for many complexions, especially women and children; because it is from that which heat does not prevail, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is to receive from the flour mill dust, and it is the kernel of wheat that hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the millstone; and you shall make it as it is, except that sieves it with egg white; and place its mixture not too thick, nor too thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it [the mixture].
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of plastering, for the treatment of a fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Prepare almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath; and grind all of them with 10 parts of myrrh, and 5 parts each of aloes, and 20 parts of alcohol; then sift them, and mix with water of alcohol, or with egg white if the dressing is warm for the weak.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this plaster [mixture].
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, it quickly restores broken bones and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of plastering, which also treats a fracture and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Prepare mugath, mess, white altheae, all ground with 10 parts of myrrh, and 5 parts each of aloes; Armenian pumice 6 times pulverized, and sifted; and make a paste with water or egg white; and administer them.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of plastering for joints and bones separated from their places; it relieves the pain and splintering of the bone, and fractures.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Wool is to be taken, immersed in vinegar and boiled oil; and placed on the location [of injury].
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 In this plaster there is no power of restoration, but it is good for the relief of hot abscesses; and it expels pain properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Method of Plaster, which restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take the leaves of figs from the deaf and the leaves of wild papaver (opium poppy); grind all of them together and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Method of the quick-acting plaster for the restoration of a broken bone, and when you wish to hasten the removal of an abscess residue.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Take equal parts of the roots of marshmallow (althea), chamomile, wild flowers, herb flour; grind all of them and make a paste with wine if the limb is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated, then make a paste of it with water of coriander, or with water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method for resolving a hard abscess during the restoration of a limb.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Take equal parts of the roots of marshmallow (althea), flax seeds, boxwood, vetch, tansy, chamomile, and wild flowers; grind all of them and make a paste with willow water, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply it according to the warmth of the limb, and the calmness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 But Hippocrates did not say in his book that it should be placed over a broken limb during its restoration, unless made of pitch, and oil; nothing else; and he said that it should have a consistency between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus thought that they should be placed over a broken limb during its restoration, which have the ability to dry heat, such as myrrh, aloes, and frankincense, and similar substances from what we mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method of plaster for injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Make a paste by grinding equal parts of barley meal, hare's wool or human hair, goose feathers, madder root (altea), and salt; and make it into an ointment.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount of the paste required for binding depends on whether pain persists, there is itching or if the fractured bone moves from its place; in such cases do not dissolve the paste for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If there is severe itching or distressing pain or swelling at the site; then urgently dissolve and remove the paste within an hour and apply a soft cloth or sponge soaked in warm water and wash the area until the itching stops and the pain subsides.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then allow the limb to rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place on it a piece of wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil; bind it over at night until you are certain that the hot swelling has passed, the limb's inflammation has subsided, and the pain has disappeared.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then apply a thin bind and small ointment; do not tighten with your first binding, but with the fine one until it heals.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all signs have been completely removed; if you need an ointment and binding, then do as before equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of what was said happens to the limb, then do not dissolve it unless after three or four or five or seven days.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when a month has passed, as the appearance of the limb from dissolution suggests, as we said, until the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh on it is close; add more to the binding than your first binding in its entirety; also increase the amount of weak food, according to the remembrance of its previous state.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see that the place of the fracture is already draining and thinning out more than is necessary, then you will know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Therefore, anoint the fracture with warm oil and water at every place where you soften it, and let this be done for three days, and then loosen the bandage a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this operation nourishment flows to the limb, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 What the foolish surgeons do instead of restoring a limb fracture, when it is not restored properly according to what is required, and is restored by crooked means, is an error in their operation, and there is great fear. And if it were right, they would have said that in their books, and operated accordingly.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have not seen anywhere the footprint of such a thing, and it is better that it not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 Chapter on making an opening in the head.
Caput III.	 Head III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 Types of fractures are various, and their shapes many; and their causes are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For there is a fracture that occurs from a blow with a sword, and the blow removes bone completely up to the siphac, which is under the bone, as an ax does in wood; hence this type of fracture is called "Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 A sword has cut something of a bone and has split its face, but the incision does not penetrate it to the end; this is called the type of fracture Kalan, that is, Absolute Leuation.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there is a wound from two kinds of fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from the fracture there is one that is compression or abrasion; and its cause is a blow with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also penetrating, which approaches the fabric (panniculus) that is under the bone; or it is on the face of the bone; and there are wounds from these two kinds of fractures, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from the fracture there is one that is hidden in the bone at the subtlety of hair; and it is a small crack, and because of this it is called this type of fracture Capillaris.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And there is a fracture caused by falling or striking with a stone and similar things that make the bone layer enter internally and form a hollow place; just like it happens to crucibles of metal when they are struck, and part of them goes into the inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 Most often this occurs in the moist heads of bones such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these types of fractures, namely separated fractures, are treated similarly; and I will return when I remember this matter completely at its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 We recognize all these types of fractures by examination on it and investigation of them with probing instruments, as well as removal of the corrupted flesh that is over them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The type of Capillaris is recognized by this, that it protrudes above the bone and is scraped off and smoothed over it with an iron; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of a fracture, consider first the conditions of the patient; then if you see among his symptoms something that indicates fear, such as cholera vomiting and extension, loss of intellect, loss of voice, fainting, acute fever, eyes discharge, redness of eyes, and similar symptoms in many other dispositions, most likely it will not be cured; but if you see symptoms that do not frighten you and hope for a recovery, then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If a wounded person comes to you first, and he is wounded during the winter days, then it is necessary that you should study the removal of the bone before the fourteenth day according to all preparations.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 If it is during the summer days, then you should hurry to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone decays due to the fat, and those things happen that I have mentioned.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of the bone has already reached the fat touching the brain, and it is with crumbling and attraction, then it is necessary that you cut the fragmented and smoothed part according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 It is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded person and scrape over the bone as much as possible for you, according to the shape of the wound and what is light on what is weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If it happens to you during the scraping of the bone, a flow of blood or hot abscess occurs, then you should apply what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 It is necessary that you fill the place with soaked rags in wine and rose oil, and make the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be safe from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the healing of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is to cut the bone with a scissors sharp blade; and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another scissors, broader than the first one; and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then also administer another scissors even wider than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 The second method is that you have a number of scissors of various sizes; some of which are wider than others, and some of them shorter than others; and they should be at the end of their sharpness, and made of iron or hardened; and use them with ease when striking the scissors, so as not to strike the head and harm it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard and tough: then it is necessary that you perforate around its circumference before you administer Incisions, with Terebrirs which are named Terebra not penetrating too deep; and they are not called this unless because they do not pass beyond the limit of the bone's flesh to that which is behind it. This is because the Terebra has a round extremity above what is beneath its head, sharp, similar to an edge, and a small circle prevents submerging, and passing through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 It is necessary for you to take a great number of these Terebrirs, each one appropriate to the thickness of the bone, until there is no more bone left for the Terebra; whose sharp extremity's size in length and width should be according to the thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the shape of three kinds of Terebrirs or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of perforating the bone's circumference when it is broken, is: that you place the Terebra on the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been pierced.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the Terebra to another place, and put what is between every hole of that size, or approximately that size.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with Incisors what is between every hole in the bone; and do it more delicately than possible near the edge of weakness, as we said, until you have removed the bone, either with your hand or with some other tools which you have prepared for that, such as tenaliae and delicate forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary to be careful with all caution, so that the Terebra or the Incisoria does not touch any part of the syphax.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you perforate the bone and separate it from the syphax, if it is continuous with that, and you remove it, it is necessary to file and make even the remaining extremity in the bone with a similar Incisoria tool.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 The translation is: "Nevertheless, it should be thin and subtle more than other incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If anything remains from the small bones and cartilage, then take them with ease, along with what is at hand from your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then, care for the wound afterwards with linen cloths, and the ointments that were mentioned.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of operation is easy and completely far from fear; this is what Galen said, and he praised it greatly; and this is his speech.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 First of all, you must begin to uncover the bone part from the place where the fracture is more violent and clear; continue doing so until you have exposed that part, and then place the rounded end of this oval incisor under it.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The rounded part does not cut anything; the sharp part of it goes along both its sides to a length as you see; so that the rounded part is connected to the siphac with the face of the sharp part incising the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike the oval incisor with a small hammer from one side until you have cut through the bone with ease, as it is rotated; and be careful that no accident occurs in the incident, which you fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 If the healer were not the most foolish of men, nor ignorant of it, nor sleeping, then if anything remained attached to the bone from the fat in certain places, he would cut it with the rounded end of the incisor and free it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone fracture does not penetrate to the fat, and what is cut away from the bone is its face, and roughness and subtle cartilage remain in it; then it is necessary for you to grind down the roughness, and remove the subtle cartilage with finer rasps which you have prepared in various quantities, so that it is possible for you to apply them more conveniently and correctly in every place according to what the operation leads you to, and the broken bone, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 It is necessary that you administer it according to your own proportion, firstly cutting the bone more broadly with those broader scrapers.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer instrument on it afterwards.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease to do this continuously until you reach the point of administering it more thinly and more finely than all the others.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each and every small crack or fine break, it is necessary to take care according to that which leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a thing that should not be hidden from any person who applies himself to this art, and it remains on top of what we have written and shown in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If a piece of tissue is detected and retained when you excavate the bone: then it is necessary that you take a linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, dip it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another linen cloth, either doubled or tripled, dip it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first piece: and do this as easily as possible on top of it, so that it does not become heavy with pus.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer a broad ligature on top of it: and do not tighten it unless by the amount that holds the wound: and leave it with this care for one day, or two days, until you are secure from the hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it and administer afterwards medicines with which excessive dryness is present: such as the roots of the lily, wheat flour, powdered incense, aristolochia and similar substances: and there should be, that you make a powder from these medicines which is sprinkled on the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer all medicine of a nature that cleanses and does not harm.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your virtue, so that the wound in your treatment is clean: let there not be dirt from ointment in it, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Let not pus gather on it entirely: because when pus gathers on a brain tissue, it corrupts it and makes it rot, and afterwards evil comes upon the sick one after that: and already this has happened with the skull, when the bone is being cleaned from it, especially when care of it is neglected, a blackness arises on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore, if such sicknesses occur as I said, know that it is certainly dangerous to avoid them.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 And if blackness does not occur except from the medicine that is put on it and it is in the virtue of this medicine to make it black: then one must take a part of honey and three parts of rose oil, and wash with them cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it on the skull: afterwards take care of it with suitable remedies for healing until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of a broken nose.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that a nose is not broken except by the two upper parts of it at once, or one of them: because they are two bones; since below it is cartilaginous, it does not break, and it does not happen to it except through injury, and twisting, and crookedness.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of the two parts of it is broken, then one must insert a small finger into the nose and align the fracture with the little finger and thumb on the outside until the nose returns to its natural shape: and this should be done skillfully, with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And be careful that your treatment does not cause pain to the sick one.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose, and it is not reached by a finger: then it is necessary that the tip of the radius be made equal, in which there should be a small swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in two parts, then make it similar (to the other); and approach with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, at the rest of the cauterizer (surgeon), with warmth.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert linen cloth (cotton swab) at the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two pieces of linen cloth if the fracture is in two parts: and there should be a bulge in the cloth of such size that it fills the nostril opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the ancient restorers said that they should be soaked (dipped) in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But that does not seem good to me, rather it is necessary that the linen cloth be soaked in egg white, made with miller's flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then release (remove) the linen cloth when the bone has set and the cartilage has hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of linen cloth after it has been covered with soft fabric; and this holds the nose fracture more tightly, and prevents the sick person from being prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary (true).
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you want, do that; if you want, do it with linen cloth.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose happens again while you are cauterizing an abscess with hot cautery, pack the nose with caustic (caustic paste), or with ointment infused in rose oil, or a little bit of opium.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if no hot abscess occurs, then it is necessary to pack it with wheat flour and incense powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft cloth upon it (the wound), and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If however the bones of the nose are broken and fragmented or ground, then it is necessary that you split them apart and extract those with instruments suitable for it.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then (you should) make an incision and care for it with that which coagulates and heals, using appropriate plasters or ointments for it.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If (the wound) should occur between the nose and the wound, then it is necessary that you treat it with linen cloths: and apply a leaden cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when it is torn apart.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is torn apart and its fracture is not accompanied by a wound: examine whether its fracture extends only outside and is not broken into two parts and bent towards the inside: in this case, the diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side of the jaw, you should insert your left index finger into the weak jaw: similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, then insert your right index finger: and push with it the bump of the fracture towards the outside with ease using your other hand from the inner part of the bone correctly, and with it even out the same.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the jaw has already been separated into two parts, then it is necessary that you apply traction from both sides, according to rectitude: until possible alignment can be achieved.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If, however, already occurs the movement or dislocation of the teeth: then tie them with a gold thread, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place a piece of wax over the fractured jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place upon it (the wound) a double cloth, and place upon the cloth a large well-made awl or a piece of shoe leather equal in length to the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above (the wound), according to how the binding is prepared for you, and its application suits it until it does not get destroyed; and command the sick man to rest quietly; and place soft foods as sorbets for his consumption.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If however you estimate that something is changing in its shape by some means; then rush, and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then straighten what has been changed from it (the wound), and apply a plaster made from flour milled into powder with egg white or with wheat bran, after you have removed the dead flesh; and place upon the plaster a soft woolen cloth.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that plaster remains attached to it (the wound), and the position of the bone does not change, leave it alone without dissolving it until it heals; or bind a fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is often bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If however a hot abscess occurs in the meantime, then administer what I have said many times for its relief until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if the fracture is with a wound, think about it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If however a piece of bone or cartilage is already separated, then be careful in this; remove those pieces of cartilage with what suits you in the removal of them from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If however the opening of the wound is narrowed, then expand it with a leech according to the quantity necessary for you.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the cartilage and nothing remains of it, or if the opening of the wound is wide; and if not, place upon it from plasters that suit for that, and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 On the restoration of the Fork (crutch), when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 Most often the crutch (fork) breaks from the anterior part near the shoulder, and its fracture occurs in one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Or it breaks and is separated into two, apart from which may occur splintering (splinters): it is easier to restore such a fracture.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or, it occurs so that the splinters are in the bone: it is more difficult to restore such a fracture.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or, it occurs so that there is an open wound along with the fracture.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the operation in this case, when there is no open wound (ulcer), is as follows: Have two assistants present, one of whom holds the splintered crutch (fork) and the other extends the neck to the opposite side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then make an even fracture with your fingers until the shape is correct, so that there should be no projection or depression.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you require more extension, then it is necessary that you place beneath the sick person's pillow a sphere (ball) made of cloth or wool: its size should be according to your need; and extend and elevate the crutch, and compress the ball with your hand until the fracture is evened out, as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot draw out the end of the crutch to the exterior (outside), because it has reached deep inside: then the sick person should lie on his back on his neck: and place under his shoulder a pillow in size, and press the assistant's arm towards the lower part, until the bone of the crutch that is deep inside is elevated upwards; at which point, straighten the fracture and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If you feel a splinter from the crutch and it moves: then it is necessary to find (locate) it on top of that, and remove the splinter easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If it is retained in the bone, then apply your instruments for cutting with one of the incision instruments you prepared for this purpose, after placing under the Furcula instrument which serves as a lever; and this instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail shell without a concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to what you need for it from the size of the bone and its part.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 But its length is also as possible for you during the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 It should have two ends, as you see; one end should be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If the wound that you divided when extracting the splinter of bone is wide and warm, then cauterize it with hot iron; then gather two lips of the wound together with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the division is small or there is a fear of warm abscess; then fill the wound with cloths and dressing according to the size of the wound cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If there occurs a warm abscess, then immerse cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 However, the setting or fixation of bone without a wound and without incision is to place plaster made from milled flour with egg white on it.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 Place soft wool over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere under the tip of it if you need it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a large blood-letting instrument which is held by the Arabs, whose width should be about one palm or a little more.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a folded dressing over the wool and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take an awl from fine wood whose width is three fingers and of similar length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then roll her up in a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then place the cloth with the star (aster) in the place of alchemilla which falls over the fracture and the place.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place alchemilla over the fracture as it is rolled, and roll it on his neck, and under the healthy part of his head (titillico sano) and under the diseased part of his head (titillico infirmo): and bring it over all parts, so that you see that the ligature holds the fracture firmly: and this is what is not hidden from you, and everything, so that the star does not remove the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 And for this reason, it is necessary to observe the diseased part every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 How often is the ligament softened and you see that the star has already been removed? Then correct it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the pillow of the sick person under his back, and place a small feather pillow for his head at night, so that when he lifts his head to sleep, help is brought from the other side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 The fracture of the collarbone should therefore be lifted through the elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind the arm to his neck and do not loosen the bandage unless it occurs due to an accidental occurrence from itching or eruption, until twelve days have passed.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add something to the ligature and let it go until it is healed and has coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The fracture of the collarbone is ligated and strengthened to a large extent for forty days, and sometimes it happens in fewer than this number of people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the healing of the fracture of the spade.
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 A spade rarely breaks, and it only breaks at its wide end; the edges do not break from it.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When therefore a place is broken from it and broken in the middle of it, and it is not recognized except by touch, then according to what it is in figure, prepare for its fracture.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And reduce it to its natural form by all means of intellect that is possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on the spot powder of millstone with egg white and soft wool, and put above it a small piece from double cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place on top of it a broad awl from subtle wood according to the quantity of the spatula, or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If however under the awl there is a hollow in any part of the spatula, then fill that hollow with soft wool, until the awl descends evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then bind above it with alum long thread, with appropriate tightness and firmness of the awl, until it is not removed from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And consider the binding every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever therefore the binding becomes soft, tighten it, and if the awl is moved from its place, let it lie weak on its healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 And the spatula is restored in twenty days, or in thirty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When therefore this number is completed, then loosen the binding: and you shall be secure.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is from bones whose fracture is not feared nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If however a fragment of bone protrudes and pierces under the skin, then cut through it, and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do what was said in the fracture of a collarbone from cauterization by hot irons, if anything happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of the chest fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 The chest is sometimes broken in the middle, and it happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 The extremities of it are most frequently broken and crushed from its accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 When its middle part, which inclines towards the lower parts, is broken and a violent pain occurs along with difficulty in breathing and coughing; and perhaps it vomits blood, and a hollow appears in the fractured bone, and it does not heal over, the restoration of it is that the sick one lies on his back on his own back: and place between his fingers a poultice.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	 Then press his shoulders and bring the ribs together from both sides or flanks with hands: and file in equality of its fracture, according to every possible way it can be achieved and converges, until the figure of the bone returns, according to what is necessary.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	 Then place on him an embrocation and a plaster, and place above it a splint made of thin wood from willow or boxwood, or similar materials, after you have wrapped it in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	 Then file it on a bandage over the broken bone so that it is not moved: and go with the binding following the roundness to the back several times, and bind it with a suitable stitch.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	 Then consider the binding in every hour, and whenever it becomes soft, bind it: and if necessity arises for its solution at the itch or corrosion that occurs in the place, or pain, or abscess; then hurry, and solve it, and remove the embrocation, and correct what has happened in the manner of treatment of it.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	 Then bring back the embrocation if you see that it faces [the fracture]: and connect a stitch to it until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	 Chapter on Restoration of Ribs, when they are broken.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
