Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	 When therefore you see that: then you know, that it is a loss, and many times he who has this happens to him dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	 Chapter on the reduction of dislocation of the collarbone, and the extremity of the shoulder.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	 The collarbone is not dislocated from the inside side because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	 And it is dislocated at times to the outside, and this can be felt.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	 And the restoration of it is that the sick one lies on his back, and extends his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	 Then the wound is closed with your fist, as it returns to its place.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	 Then lay an ointment on it and powder, and press it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	 But the extremities that follow the elbow should not be separated from it, except rarely.
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is dislocated on some day: then it is necessary that it be reduced and made equal according to what I have said, and what is prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	 Then lay an ointment on it and powder, and bind it.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	 And command the sick one to adhere to calmness and rest until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	 And with this same treatment, the arm extremity is reduced when it is separated from its place as well.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	 Chapter on the Reduction of Dislocation of the Shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	 Know that the shoulder is not dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	 One of these is that it dislocates to the part of the armpit towards the lower side.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	 The second is that it dislocates to the chest area.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	 And perhaps it may dislocate to the upper part of the shoulder: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	 It is not dislocated behind, because of the spine.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	 It is not dislocated in front, because of nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	 And indeed it most frequently dislocates and goes towards the lower side turned into the armpit; especially in those who have less flesh.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	 Because it goes out quickly in them, and enters quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	 In those whose flesh is numerous, there is, on the contrary, that which goes out with difficulty, and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	 And perhaps it happens to some people a blow or fall, and the shoulder is dislocated and it is thought because of this that it has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	 Therefore, one should experiment that, until you are certain of its condition, and then proceed in the treatment of it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	 A dislocation is known when it is turned towards the lower part and towards the tip of the little finger: and distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy shoulder.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	 For you find among them a manifest difference, and you find in the head of the shoulder a hollow, and below the tip of the little finger, when touched, the head of the shoulder seems to be an egg: and a weak person cannot bring his hand to his ear nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	 And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upward: then you find a clear touch, and it is not hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	 The reduction of this kind of dislocation is easy when it is recent, or if the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	 And the reduction of it is that you lift the hand of the assistant to a higher place.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	 Then put your thumbs below its tip, and lift the joint with strength to a higher place to its own place: and the assistant lifts his hand, and extends it upward.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	 Then he puts it downward, for indeed he quickly returns.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	 But if it does not return through what has been said, and from the beginning when the dislocation happened there are many days: then it is necessary that the weak person be bathed in warm water, and a poultice administered which softens and soothes, as if they decoct roots of althea, and fenugreek, and melilotus in water, and it is administered.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	 The sick man lies on his back: and let there be placed beneath his navel a sphere and wool which is equal between softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	 The physician places his heel upon the sphere, and raises the head of the arm with force, and draws the hand of the sick to below.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	 Another servant holds the head of the sick man, so that it is not moved downwards; for he immediately returns.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	 And if you wish, do this in this way: and it is that the present man who is taller than the sick man should stand on the side, and insert his arm under the navel of the sick man; and raise the navel upwards, until the sick man is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	 Another servant pulls the hand of the sick man to below his belly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	 If the sick man is lightweight: then it is necessary that he is suspended with something else, in order to weigh him down; for dislocation immediately returns.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	 And it can also be done in another way: and it is that a long piece of wood is placed on the ground, whose head is round shaped like a mortar handle; but not too large or too small.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	 Then place beneath the sick man when the heads of the logs are placed on his head; and the sick man should stand along the length of the log.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 Then the hand is extended to below from the other side, and the body is extended from the other side with force; for dislocation returns to its place quickly.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	 If the reduction is difficult by all that we have said, then use this care: and it is to take a log whose length is the quantity of two arms, and its width the quantity of four fingers, and its thickness the quantity of two fingers; and round head, so that it can be inserted deeply into the opening of the navel, in this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	 Then, cover the round head with soft cloths, so as not to hurt the weak wood.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	 Place it under the sensitive area of the weak, so that the hand or arm can be extended over the wood to its lower parts. Then tie the wood and the arm and the end of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	 Then place the arm over the step on the ladder, and extend the hand to its lower parts, and let the rest of the body hang suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	 The joint then enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	 When the entry is completed as much as possible, then it is necessary to place a ball of equal size made from wool under the sensitive area.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	 Then apply a plaster prepared from milled flour with beeswax and egg white over the whole shoulder as it is customarily done.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	 Then bind under the sensitive area a suitable bandage. Roll the bandage over the plaster above it. Connect the hand to the neck of the same person and let it not move for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	 It is necessary to place a sparse food until the limb recovers strength; for it heals more quickly in this way.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	 Then, after seven or five days, stretch it out and let it be washed with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	 If it becomes hard and is not softened, then it is already healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	 If the joint is dislocated frequently due to moisture that occurs there or due to some other cause, then it is necessary to administer a cautery with three holes as mentioned in the chapter on cauteries.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	 If this is done completely and the bandage is loosened after seven days, and the joint does not become firm, and the plaster and bandage are applied to it several times without becoming hard, and it falls and cannot be raised to a higher position: then you know that the nerves that go to the head of the shoulder have been cut or stretched or softened. And you know that the joint will never heal in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	 Dislocation which occurs towards the breast and nipple, or reduction to the rear, is made by pushing and extending with hands until it returns; then, additional compression and care should be administered until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	 If there is heaviness in the limb after healing and sluggishness of motion, then the afflicted should use baths many times until that heaviness is relieved and it returns to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	 Treatment for shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	 Know that the joining of the shoulder is dislocated with difficulty, and it also returns with difficulty; this dislocation occurs in all directions, but especially in front or to the rear.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	 And the dislocation of this joint is not hidden from you: because it falls under your sight and touch, according to whatever shape it may be dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	 And when you join a dislocated shoulder with the healthy one, it is made clear to you manifestly.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	 Indeed, the joint should be hollowed out, and the arm cannot double, nor can the humerus touch it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 It is necessary to rush and reduce the dislocation immediately, before a hot abscess occurs.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	 For if a hot abscess occurs, the reduction becomes difficult; and perhaps it does not heal at all, especially when it is to the rear.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	 Indeed, every kind of dislocation is worse and more painful; and death often accompanies it many times.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 And the restoration of it when it is one that can be reduced, is to extend the hand with two hands; and the arm should be stretched out, and the physician's hands should be above and below the shoulder, and he himself pushes the joint with his fingers or the root of his palm until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	 If it is a dislocation towards the front: then he shall return it so that he divides his hand with the dislocated hand until he strikes with the root of his palm the elbow which is dislocated.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	 If the dislocation does not obey in reduction, then administer a strong and powerful traction; and it is to extend the arm by two servants; and they shall hold it also, so that it may not be moved during the traction.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	 Then the arm is turned to all sides after it slipped over his hand, covered with a double cloth or a broad bandage.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	 And when the physician touches with his hand the joint, he shall bind it with oil; so that it may be one of those things which aid in lubricity at the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	 Then push the joint with a strong impulse until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	 After its reduction, it is necessary that a plaster be placed upon it, which contains styptics and drying with egg white; and it shall be tied with an appropriate ligature.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	 And the arm of the sick person shall be suspended from the neck for some days.
Deinde soluatur.	 Then it is loosened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	 If the joint is strengthened in its place, then loosen the bandage from it and release it.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 And if you see that the joint is not bound well, then repeat the plaster, and bandage, and leave it for some days until it becomes bound.
Deinde solue ipsam.	 Then loosen it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	 If there is pain after the reduction of the joint and it has motion: then administer humectation in the bath, and fine friction, and compression until it lines up, or place upon the joint, that is, fat of the ram's wool.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	 Then bind it and leave it on it for a day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	 Then remove it and insert it into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	 When it sweats, then rub the joined part with moderate friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	 Then, three times on the same place with a heated iron, and at each introduction of the bath until it becomes soft.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	 And if you wish, place upon it cow dung, moistened and heated with butter, and press down on it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	 Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	 It becomes soft and returns to its original condition.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	 Section on the treatment of dislocations by Albucasis.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	 Almahassem's hand is often dislocated, that is, the join between arm and hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	 The reduction of this dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	 Contrariwise, other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	 However, it is necessary that speed should be present in the reduction of this dislocation within the hour when it occurs, before the place is allowed to become swollen; or else a warm abscess may occur in that place.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	 The reduction of this dislocation is as follows: Place Almahassem's weak hand on a table, and extend the minister's hand; and let the physician place his palm on the prominence of the joint, and push it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	 However, it should be considered if the palm has already retreated into the wrist of the hand; then let the weak side place its back of the hand on the table for extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is proceeding towards the back of the hand, then let the position of his hand be internally on the table, that is, the inner part of the hand should be placed on the table, so that the physician can fall on the prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	 If it therefore returns immediately, that is good; and if not, then press it with a dressing on the swelling abscess; and leave it alone, without repeating the procedure.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	 If it does not endure [the reduction], nor can you make another attempt upon it, after the days have passed, yet the connection remains according to its twistiness; and nothing harms the weak except what is softened by the hand, and nothing can be tightened: then you will know that the nerves have been cut or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	 There is no skill in it except to tighten it with a cautionery near its loss.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	 And perhaps that does not benefit it at all.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	 When therefore Almahassem does not return, then place upon him an ointment as we have said.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	 Then it is tightened and allowed for five days; afterwards it is loosened and allowed, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	 If its motion is deprived and something of gravity happens to it: then soften it with warm water and rubbing several times until it becomes soft.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	 [Chapter on the Treatment of Finger Dislocations.]
Caput XXX.	 Chapter XXX.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	 When a finger is dislocated in any direction or the finger is dislocated to the back of the palm or its ventrum: then extend the finger, and push the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	 Then hold the head of the finger and suspend it turned to the side to which it is dislocated, and leave it for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	 Then suspend it, and extend it until it becomes straight on that day itself.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	 When therefore it is night, tie it according to the said account; and do not cease to loosen it during the day; and exercise it with movement; and tie it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 Do that for several days until it is tightened.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	 And likewise do the same if it is dislocated to the palm of the hand; and tie it to that part itself, and perform your first operation on it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	 And similarly do with it when it is dislocated to other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	 On the treatment of spondylolisthesis of the spine.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter XXXI.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	 When it happens to someone that the vertebra of the back or neck is completely dislocated, or many vertebrae are removed from their places: then there is no cure in it, because death approaches the weak.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	 And a sign of this is that the weakness of the patient goes out involuntarily and it cannot be held; and often some of his limbs become soft or two legs of his, or two arms, or one of them; or a vertebra is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	 For it is often removed (dislocated), which often happens for its removal in four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	 Therefore, what is dislocated towards the rear, is called a humpback.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	 The cure of this (humpback) is that you consider whether it happens from childhood; then there is no cure in it and there is no healing at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	 But in that which happens by accident, or by blow, or similar things, the ancients have already spoken of the methods of treatment at length in a long speech.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	 It does not often return with recovery.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	 I myself have already abbreviated from that which does not leave much hope for recovery due to my proximity to the intention of the subject; and in my explanation, I have presented it, and formed its instrument differently from how they presented it and explained it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	 Therefore, I say that in a humpback which happens from the front part, there is no cure and no healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	 And similarly, in one which happens on both sides as well.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	 And it is not cured from them, except for that which happens on the back properly, as I said; and there is a way to stretch out the weak person face down on an equal flat surface nearly up against a wall; and a wet rug is spread under him so as not to injure his chest.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	 Then place a straight stick fixed in the fire on the ground, at the end of the foot, about its head: and another stick about its feet at the other end of the foot: and let the servant hold the stick, and it not be fixed in the fire.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	 And let another servant hold the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	 Then cover the head of the sick one and tie a soft bandage firmly around his neck, and extend the end of the bandage to the stick that is at his head and bind it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	 Then tie another bandage above his ankles and above his knees, and at the joints of his limbs.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	 Then gather all the bindings together and tie them to the other stick that is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	 Then each servant should extend the bandage to the part of the stick and the two sticks shall not be moved from their places where they are fixed, but they shall not be fastened, as we said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	 And the physician should place his hands on the hip bone with force until it returns or he places a board over it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	 Then he connects his feet to the board until it returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	 If it does not return by this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	 And make a hole in the wall near the sick one, into which the end of the board is to enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	 Then place the middle of the board on the hip bone.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	 And the physician should place his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	 And tie it tightly until the hip bone is dislocated and returns to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	 Then, if you wish, work with a roller that is turned by hand: and it is so that you press into the ground near the head of the sick one at the end of the foot two sticks, whose length is an arm: and at the head of him at the end of the foot two sticks.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	 And let the length be one palm between every stick; and already a hole has been made in every place where the tourniquet runs; and let all sticks be firmly fixed on the ground, so that they do not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	 And insert a round stick; and there is a tourniquet in which the ligament is revolved in two holes of two sticks.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	 And at its end there is a hole, in which the stick is fastened, whose length is one palm plus the part that is revolved; and similarly on two other sticks.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	 Then tighten the ligaments which you tied on the chest of the sick man at the tourniquet that is near his head; and the ligaments which you tied on his legs at the tourniquet that is near his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	 Then stand by every tourniquet an assistant who will twist his hand with a linen cloth, with which the tourniquet is revolved; and the doctor presses the sponge, as we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	 Here is the form of the tourniquet that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	 Then, when the sponge returns and the place is pressed again, then it is necessary that you put on an asringent plaster with egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	 Then apply a woolen material (stuffing).
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	 After that, place on top of the plaster a star-shaped piece of wood, whose width is three fingers or approximately so.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	 And its length should be such that it covers the hump and the healthy part of the sponge.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	 Then bind it with the ligament as we have said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	 And the sick man should be given subtle food until he is cured.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	 If something remains as a hump in the place at the end of healing, then it is necessary to administer medicines that soften and soothe, with the use of the board that I have mentioned for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	 And now the plate of lead is administered (to the patient).
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	 Whenever an eminence happens at the last vertebra of the back; and it is thought to be a dislocation, and that bone which projects (is present).
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	 Therefore, it is not fitting for this medicine to be assumed presumptuously; perhaps it will cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	 Chapter on the treatment of a dislocated ankle.
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	 Know that the articulation of the ankle and the articulation of the shoulder do not occur except by dislocation; nor does what happens to the other joints occur in them from a slight displacement or concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	 And indeed, the articulation of the ankle is dislocated according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 Because it is dislocated towards the front and towards the back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 It is mainly dislocated towards the inner parts; it is scarcely dislocated towards the front and the back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	 The treatment for dislocation of this [bone] towards the inner parts is as follows: because when you join a weak leg to a sound one, it is longer; and the knee of the weak one protrudes more than that of the healthy one, and the weak cannot double its foot at the groin; and there is a place behind the groin that has been pierced with a hot iron due to this, because the head of the hip has reached there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	 The sign of [bone] dislocation towards the outer parts is that its symptoms are opposite to these symptoms [mentioned earlier].
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	 The sign of [bone] dislocation towards the front is that it stretches a healthy leg to its full extent; however, it does not double the limb without pain in the knee; and if he tries to walk on it, he cannot do so towards the front; and his urine is retained, and his groin is pierced with an iron, and during walking, there is kicking of it against the heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	 The sign of [bone] dislocation towards the back is that it does not stretch out the knee nor can it double it before doubling the groin; and its leg is even shorter than the other; and the groin is softened, and the head of the hip is at the place [of the dislocation].
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	 The reduction of this dislocation is as follows: one should consider then, if the dislocation is old, which has become fixed in the patient.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	 Then, if you administer reduction of it and it remains in its position; then there is no treatment at all in this case.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	 Therefore, one should not make a hasty presumption about him.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	 In the case of a recent dislocation, which belongs to one of four dislocation types; then, you should hasten to this, that you apply pressure and stretch it both towards the inner parts and towards the outer parts, and move it left and right; perhaps it will return and require no further treatment.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	 If it does not return in this manner, then it is necessary to prepare a strong assistant and extend his leg from the lower part; either with his own hands, or with a strap that can be tied above the knee: and another assistant shall extend his hand upward, so that he may introduce his hands beneath the armpits.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	 Then tie a gentle strap over the root of the hip and hold the end of another strap.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	 And let its extension be either from the front of the groin to the neck part, or from behind to the back part.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	 And let their extension be equal in all parts, until the weak one is raised from the ground with his body and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	 For this kind of extension is the common shape of the four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	 If therefore the dislocation returns as we have said, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary for all kinds to do what I will say regarding its treatment.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 In the reduction of its own kind, when the dislocation is toward the interior parts, it is necessary for the weak one to lie on his healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	 Then place a strap over the root of the hip, where it is between the head of the hip and the place that is below the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	 Then extend the strap upward from the groin to a higher part of the body, to the neck part.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	 Then another strong assistant shall take his arms and reduce the large place of the weak hip, and extend it with a vigorous extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	 Now it returns to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	 And this kind is easier than the other kinds of treatment, by which this member is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	 If it is excused above you and does not obey you for the introduction with this kind of treatment altogether; then it is necessary to tie together both the weak feet with a strong strap, gentle, over both heels and both knees: and let the length of each one be four fingers in breadth: and let the weak leg be extended more than the other by two digits.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	 Then the sick person is suspended over the head of a beam, which should be in the house; and let the length of it from the ground be equal to two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 Then order a strong youth to brace the head and thighs; another youth supports the sick person with him; and another youth pushes, bracing the thighs with strength, for the joint returns to its place quickly with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	 In its reduction, when there is a dislocation towards the outside, it is necessary that the sick person lies on a platform, as we have said in one who has a hump.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	 And bind the ligament on his foot, tightly for the sick person, and on his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	 Then two beams are placed, one at his feet, and another at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	 Then place an additional beam in the middle of the platform, firmly fixed; on which are rolled wet cloths, so as not to hurt the sick person; and let there be a beam between his thighs, so that he is not drawn towards the lower parts during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	 Then all the assistants should go to their places, and the doctor equalizes the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	 If therefore it yields to reversal, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	 And if not, place it on the platform and press it equally, as we have said in one who has a hump.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Nevertheless, the sick person should lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	 And when dislocation is towards the front, then it should be extended quickly the leg of the sick person; and this has the same story on the platform; and the doctor puts his right hand's palm on the thigh of the sick person.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	 Then bend him with one hand, and with this bending put him extended towards the lower parts to the knee-part.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	 If dislocation is towards the back: then it is not necessary that the sick person should be extended towards the lower parts and raised up from the ground; rather it is necessary that he should be placed on a hard surface, as it is also necessary if his ankle is dislocated towards the outside, according to what we have said about lying him on two surfaces: and it should be on his face and the extended ligaments: according to what we have recently said.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	 It is necessary that a compression be administered with a board even over the joint to which it extends, when reduction is completed as required.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 And the sign of its reduction will not be hidden to you: and it is, that you extend two legs of the weak: and when you see them equal, and the weak man stretches his leg, and expands it without dislocation: then you will know that the limb has returned as required: then join two hips, and apply plaster, and bind with lint, that is, wheel: thus, so that it does not move sideways to any part: and the weak man remains quiet for three days or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	 Then loosen the binding, and the plaster, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see them equal in position, then you will know that the dislocation is now fixed: release therefore the weak man for walking.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	 And if you see something softening: then return, and apply plaster to it, and bind it according to your first binding: and leave it for three days as well.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	 Then loosen that and make it slow in walking on both sides for some days until it recovers well.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	 Chapter on Dislocations of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	 The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	 It is dislocated to the outside, to the inside, and downwards, that is, backwards.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	 And it is not dislocated forwards.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	 And the sign of its dislocation is that you command the weak man to apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	 If it does not cling with the hip: then you will know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	 And the restoration of all ways of dislocation is that you make the weak man sit upright, so that he can extend his leg if possible over it, and let his back touch his face: and put his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	 Then attach (it) to the leg with your hands, and straighten them on top of the leg.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	 Apply with the palm of your hand two sides of the leg with force.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	 Let another servant extend the foot until the leg returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	 And a sign of return is that the thigh and shin adhere gently, not laboriously.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	 Then apply plasters to it, and make the thigh and shin adhere.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 Then bind them together with ointment for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	 Then loosen (them).
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	 Let the sick person not walk for some days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	 If the reduction of it (leg) is refused to you, then administer a strong extension with cords, whose treatment for dislocation of the ankle has been described earlier, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	 Chapter on the cure of the dislocation of the heel.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XLII.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	 The heel is sometimes moved slightly out of place and at other times it is dislocated completely.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	 And its dislocation happens either towards the inside or outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	 A sign of its dislocation is that you see the heel swollen and protruding towards the direction to which it has been dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	 But the cure for its removal is easy reduction, and it is as follows: (it) should be extended with ease by hands and aligned until it returns to its place.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	 When it is completely dislocated, in its treatment it is necessary to make the sick person sit straight and a strong servant hold him from behind in the middle of his back.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	 Then hold the foot with your right hand from above it and with your left hand from below the foot at the ankle.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	 Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	 Then with two fingers (on) the left side.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	 Extend (your hand) with the left, and push the chest with your foot turned to the right leg without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	 Do that twice, as we have told you.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	 Then push the chest with your foot to the leg on the third time and you draw (out) the splinter.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	 If it comes back in the first or second time according to this method and you see the foot equalized, that is good; and if not, then repeat the operation on it, because it will come out again.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	 If its reduction with what we have told you is forbidden to you: then make the sick person lie on his back on the ground and place a firm wooden peg firmly fixed in the ground so that he falls between his thighs; and now you have rolled him over onto it with a cloth, so that he does not hurt the sick person.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	 Then the servant takes his thigh; afterwards, another servant extends his leg or with his hands, or with a strap that binds around its neck.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	 Then all the servants extend themselves in opposition to his extension; and the peg remains standing between the thighs of the sick person holding him so that his body is not drawn downward by the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	 Then the doctor equalizes the displacement with his hands, and another servant holds the healthy leg downwards.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	 For a dislocation comes back quickly.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	 When the dislocation returns and the recovery is declared to you, then put plaster and wax, and bind it tightly with bandages, and bind the foot with a bandage to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	 And it is necessary that you be careful or afraid of the nerves that are above the heel at the back, so that the bandage is not too tight and hurts them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then let him go for two or three days.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	 If the ligament is softened, tie it up; then dissolve it on the third or fourth day, and forbid the sick person from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	 If he attempts to walk before that time, there is no certainty that it will not be dislocated again and spoiled; nor will he receive cure after that.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	 If it happens to him that there is a hot abscess: then it is necessary that you administer to his sedation what we previously described for treatment elsewhere, and apply embrocation until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	 Chapter on the dislocation of fingers and cure.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter 35.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	 It is necessary that it be equated which is dislocated with little extension without effort; and indeed, this is not difficult but easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	 If the dislocation is in some nodes of the back of the foot: then it is necessary that the sick person make his foot sit on a level place with the ground or on a table; and he stands as if walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	 Then you stand, and put your foot upon that which protrudes from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	 Then press it with your foot with force until it returns and you see it already equated, and the protrusion does not appear in its place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	 Then put a board under his foot's belly which takes the whole foot, with two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	 Then tie it up with a bandage for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	 Then dissolve it and let him rest from walking for many days until it is bound and secured against relapse.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	 Chapter on the types of dislocations with wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	 When something happens to it and you attempt its cure and restoration, death often occurs; therefore, one should not presume over its cure unless he is experienced in the art of long use, merciful, pious, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous: and that he uses only remedies that calm hot abscesses, and leaves the sick person to divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	 If thou seest not, or hopest for salvation from destruction with mildness of disease, and where something appears of hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	 Strive therefore for the reduction of it at once at the beginning of the matter, before a hot abscess occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	 If the limb therefore returns as we desire, then administer a regime which restrains the abscess; and take care of the wound with that which agrees with it from dry ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	 If there is a dislocation together with a fracture, and separated sores occur on the bone, then strive for the removal of them, and do as we said in simple diseases in their places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	 And beware according to your strength, and keep yourself from entering into the way of fear; according to what my discourse preceded for you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	 For that is better for thee at thy Creator, and more lasting for thy glory, and more safe for thy body among them in thy time.
